headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk to us a little bit about the benefits from rates as they come through. Obviously, your commentary that NII will be even flattish in the first quarter adjusted for day count and even with some securities gains in the numbe
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk to us a little bit about the benefits from rates as they come through. Obviously, your commentary that NII will be even flattish in the first quarter adjusted for day count and even with some securities gains in the numbers this quarter, presumes that a nice helper from that first move. And you guys are really conservative on your deposit beta thoughts when you talked about them previously. I know probably haven't seen much change yet. But how are you expecting to deposit pay for the act? And has there been any change to your modeling expectations about what might come through as we get through the first couple of hikes?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So  -- just on NII, yes, we are seeing embedded in that sort of NII flat to up slightly. We are seeing a nice lift associated with the rate hike in December across businesses as well as the continued benefit of the mix towards loans in our balance sheet.
componenttext: So  -- just on NII, yes, we are seeing embedded in that sort of NII flat to up slightly. We are seeing a nice lift associated with the rate hike in December across businesses as well as the continued benefit of the mix towards loans in our balance sheet. But we were flatter in our NII this quarter by $178 million on securities gains and CIO. So that's going to mean the comparison is challenging and then day count is obviously seasonal. And that's on the dynamic we are seeing the rate benefit. We do expect to see it, as I said, in my remarks for the full year. Look, we think we are appropriately conservative on deposit reserves. It is not -- it is way too early to have any idea but that's really nothing, hasn't moved yet. And so our job and what we are doing is paying very close attention to the invested landscape and these deposits that we're talking about, that have the high basis are valuable deposits with valuable clients for us and we want to be competitive and pay fair rates. But it's so early in the movie that we haven't changed much in our modeling assumptions.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, my second question, if I can ask an x-energy credit question. A lot of concerns that we're going to get into some type of broader deterioration of which your number showed no signs of heading towards. What are you looking for? Are you seeing any sig
componenttext: Okay, my second question, if I can ask an x-energy credit question. A lot of concerns that we're going to get into some type of broader deterioration of which your number showed no signs of heading towards. What are you looking for? Are you seeing any signals of x-energy changes in either delinquencies or watch trends? I know you're still comfortable with kind of that low force type of charge of expectation that you guys had talked about previously.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So energy, metals and mining, we're watching very closely, industries that kind of -- could have knock on effects like industrials and transportation. But we're not seeing anything broadly in our portfolio right now. We're just watching very closely, whic
componenttext: So energy, metals and mining, we're watching very closely, industries that kind of -- could have knock on effects like industrials and transportation. But we're not seeing anything broadly in our portfolio right now. We're just watching very closely, which is why -- now obviously, you can take our reserve builds number and you can say it's almost essentially all made up of oil and gas, and metals and mining. And behind the scenes, we've had upgrades and downgrades of a number of other different companies across sectors but nothing particularly thematic yet. But we're watching.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now that we have the credit card, commercial bank, middle market, large corporate credit is just good as it's ever been. So obviously, it's going to get a little bit worse. I wouldn't call it a cycle per se. If you have a recession, you will see a normal
componenttext: Now that we have the credit card, commercial bank, middle market, large corporate credit is just good as it's ever been. So obviously, it's going to get a little bit worse. I wouldn't call it a cycle per se. If you have a recession, you will see a normal cyclical increase in all of those losses. We're not forecasting recession. We always think that the U.S. economy looks pretty good at this point.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think you talked about some of this scenario and in terms of [indiscernible] surcharge now estimated at 3.5. I'm just curious. I think if the numbers are right, you took down [indiscernible] and those are about $3.4 trillion, $21 billion in Level 3 a
componenttext: So I think you talked about some of this scenario and in terms of [indiscernible] surcharge now estimated at 3.5. I'm just curious. I think if the numbers are right, you took down [indiscernible] and those are about $3.4 trillion, $21 billion in Level 3 assets, $50 billion in non-op deposits. You said that you don't want to be an outlier so you're whittling that down. I'm curious of the driving force behind it. What kind of revenue give up there is in such a move like this because we like it and thoughts on the go forward.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So look, we talked about achieving 4% last quarter I think and -- disclosure we were quite close to 3.5. At that point, it becomes increasingly compelling to want to look at the margin or what you could do to get within the bucket and so that is what
componenttext: Yes. So look, we talked about achieving 4% last quarter I think and -- disclosure we were quite close to 3.5. At that point, it becomes increasingly compelling to want to look at the margin or what you could do to get within the bucket and so that is what we did in the fourth quarter is spent time really focusing on getting to that achievable boundary, which we dropped at that point as well. And remember, it's not -- nothing in the year that we started the year thinking we would exit $100 billion of nonoperating deposit and while that's still there could be some volatility in that number, of course. We've almost double that or double that, in fact. So we got some wind to our backs in doing it. It's also the case that when you get the entire business and company attuned to the sense of urgency and desire to want to be increasingly efficient in this way, that, at the margin in our 100 different things, little benefit the crew. So the correct, about 3.5 weeks to adjust, in fact, the 3.5 bucket as we estimated. It's not as much important whether we're basis points or surcharge points below or above. It's much more what we do now to get safely in the bucket and that's going to still take work. So that's why, we'll obviously talk to you more about this at Investor Day. In terms of the give out from an economic perspective, we wouldn't have done it at any cost. We have done it because we think it is important to do, because we think it's going to be constructive for the company and because the revenue give outs were not significant, but they weren't wider. But to be able to reduce a constraint that it is in one way or another likely to bind us or in multiple ways, in fact, likely to bind us. It was a I think a very good track.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was done effectively client by client. Make sure we're trying to do the right thing for our clients, not just trimming our balance sheet down or hurting people.
componenttext: It was done effectively client by client. Make sure we're trying to do the right thing for our clients, not just trimming our balance sheet down or hurting people.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. I just have one quick follow-up on Ken's last question. If 2/3 of the economy is consumer lag, you look at all your early stage delinquencies like Ken said, and Jamie to your comments, things look okay. I hate putting words in your mouth but
componenttext: Fair enough. I just have one quick follow-up on Ken's last question. If 2/3 of the economy is consumer lag, you look at all your early stage delinquencies like Ken said, and Jamie to your comments, things look okay. I hate putting words in your mouth but what do you think the disconnect then is between what's going on in the markets versus what's going on in the trends in your business, both in terms of growth and forward-looking credit looks?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The U.S. economy has been chugging along with 2% to 2.5% growth for a better part of 5 years now. The last year, it's created 5 million jobs and when you look at the actual household formation, car sales, wage, people working, it still looks okay. Corpora
componenttext: The U.S. economy has been chugging along with 2% to 2.5% growth for a better part of 5 years now. The last year, it's created 5 million jobs and when you look at the actual household formation, car sales, wage, people working, it still looks okay. Corporate credit is quite good. Small business formation is not back to where it was but it's quite good. Household formation is going up. So obviously, market turmoil, we all look at it everyday but I'm not sure if most 143 million Americans look at it that much who have jobs and you have a big change in the world out there. People are getting adjusting to China's slowing down. You have commodity prices go down like that, your big winners and losers, the oil companies are losers, consumers benefit. Brazil gets hurt. India benefits. South Korea benefits, Japan benefits and those kind of trickling waters. And hopefully, this will all settle down and it's not the beginning of something really bad.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Foran with Autonomous.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Foran with Autonomous.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The disclosure on oil and gas is really helpful and I was wondering if you could just walk through something similar on metals and mining. So you gave us the I think you said $68 million of full year reserve build, and you gave us the nonsignificant, if t
componenttext: The disclosure on oil and gas is really helpful and I was wondering if you could just walk through something similar on metals and mining. So you gave us the I think you said $68 million of full year reserve build, and you gave us the nonsignificant, if things stay where they are. Can you give us the balance and then is there a comparable $500 million to $750 million stress test for oil and gas or stressed case? Is there a comparable, what is the stress case if broader commodities of metals and mining comes out worse?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So our total reserves on balance sheet for metals and mining, not withstanding we built 60-odd million dollars. This year it's over $200 million. So the coverage ratio is pretty good. The exposure is about 1/3, I haven't got a precise number in fron
componenttext: Okay. So our total reserves on balance sheet for metals and mining, not withstanding we built 60-odd million dollars. This year it's over $200 million. So the coverage ratio is pretty good. The exposure is about 1/3, I haven't got a precise number in front of me, they are 1/3 the size of our exposure to oil and gas so that's 2% of our overall wholesale credit exposure. So considerably more modest, which is why if energy prices and general commodities weakness and stress stays where it is right now, even for an extended period, we would think that the incremental reserves will be considerably more modest.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And it's also -- that one is mostly name by name. It's not big asset base reserves. It just means to be big corporate credits name by name.
componenttext: And it's also -- that one is mostly name by name. It's not big asset base reserves. It just means to be big corporate credits name by name.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so both oil and gas and metals and mining in our portfolio, our oil and gas is close to 60% investment grade, metals and mining, about 1/2.
componenttext: And so both oil and gas and metals and mining in our portfolio, our oil and gas is close to 60% investment grade, metals and mining, about 1/2.

componenttext: And then on, I guess staying with credit on our home equities and the whole issue of recast from interest home to amortizing. headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so with respect to home equity recast, I mean remember the majority of the problematic home equity underwriting was 2005 thorugh '08. So here we are at the beginning '16, with the sort of pig still in the python. But we're monitoring it closely, and
componenttext: Yes, so with respect to home equity recast, I mean remember the majority of the problematic home equity underwriting was 2005 thorugh '08. So here we are at the beginning '16, with the sort of pig still in the python. But we're monitoring it closely, and we have some recasts that have happened. Obviously, interest rates are low. Home price appreciation on the other hand open to the puts and takes. We've been monitoring it. I would say at the margin or more than the margin at early stage is coming in better than we had modeled and remember, from an incurred loss perspective, we would consider these [indiscernible] to be largely incurred. So we try to reserve them to the best of our ability. So we felt good about our reserve, but I think we've disclosed them. But so far from a performance perspective, I would say slightly better than our models, but we continue to monitor it because it's still relatively early.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes of the line of Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marianne, I know that the Basel Committee put out their fundamental review of the trading proposal this morning. So clearly, no one's really had time to go through it in detail. I'm sure you have already gone through the prior proposal and done the trials
componenttext: Marianne, I know that the Basel Committee put out their fundamental review of the trading proposal this morning. So clearly, no one's really had time to go through it in detail. I'm sure you have already gone through the prior proposal and done the trials for the last couple of years. The proposal's better than what had been. The ruling is better than what the proposal most recently would have been. Just wanted to get a sense from you as to how you can manage to this 2019 implementation time frame? Are there things set in motion already? Or is this something that you would start from here? And if you could just give us some broad strokes on how you think about overall impact, that would be helpful.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So obviously, you'll forgive me because we've been on call since it came out but yes, we have been working on this for years. The problem with this particular rule is that as you stated, based upon the 4 QAS that were done, there were some -- I would
componenttext: Yes. So obviously, you'll forgive me because we've been on call since it came out but yes, we have been working on this for years. The problem with this particular rule is that as you stated, based upon the 4 QAS that were done, there were some -- I would characterize significant challenges with respect to all those and we were expecting there to be a number of meaningful changes and there have been, in many cases, meaningful improvements. But it's very technical and there's been a lot of changes so we need to filter it to figure out net-net everything, although it is clear that net-net, despite the fact that the state and intention of the committee wasn't necessarily to increase market with capital across the industry. It will be higher. But by how much, it's really going to need to be sifted through and for that same reason, for both the same reasons -- I'm sorry, for the reason that the rule has not been stable and there have been significant questions, many of which have been either addressed or partially addressed and many, I guess that have not. It would have been premature to have taken any actions in advance of figuring out where this has landed and as you know, the period that complies 3 years. So it's more of start from here to figure out how to manage with this after we see through the details. So I wish I would -- were able to give a little bit more of a detailed answer but we're going to need to take the time to go through it.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. I totally understand that and I guess my basic question is, there's -- you can take action as opposed to just deal with what? The current decision would be for your, there are actions that you can take to reduce the impact?
componenttext: Right. I totally understand that and I guess my basic question is, there's -- you can take action as opposed to just deal with what? The current decision would be for your, there are actions that you can take to reduce the impact?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well then, there are always actions that we can take to reduce the impact. And so -- we have to think about them in the context of our overall capital optimization program. And again, if there are -- if some of the things that we host -- and I honestly, I
componenttext: Well then, there are always actions that we can take to reduce the impact. And so -- we have to think about them in the context of our overall capital optimization program. And again, if there are -- if some of the things that we host -- and I honestly, I've been on call since it came out but some of the things that we hope were going to be addressed have not. They could have had or may have meaningful impact on specific types of activity. And we will have to react accordingly. And yes, we will take actions if that's the right answer. I wish I could give you more details but we just need to go through it.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Chubak with Nomura.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Chubak with Nomura.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I had a couple of questions on capital. The first relates to the RWA progress, which it's a price positively in the year by about $50 billion ahead of expectations. And I was just hoping you can give a better sense, Marianne, just given some your prepa
componenttext: So I had a couple of questions on capital. The first relates to the RWA progress, which it's a price positively in the year by about $50 billion ahead of expectations. And I was just hoping you can give a better sense, Marianne, just given some your prepared remarks as to how much of that incremental $50 billion reduction was a function of more proactive litigation efforts, maybe even tied to the recent mitigation efforts that you guys had talked about, which should presumably remain in the run rate versus balance sheet shrinkage that maybe due to the [indiscernible] environment that we're experiencing today.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So -- I would say that based upon sort of 4 quarter balance sheet, given that market risk was a driver, given that balance sheet levels were the driver particularly on standardized. We could give back on standardized as much as 10, 20 bps of capital
componenttext: Yes. So -- I would say that based upon sort of 4 quarter balance sheet, given that market risk was a driver, given that balance sheet levels were the driver particularly on standardized. We could give back on standardized as much as 10, 20 bps of capital -- of the 10.7% capital accretion. But the bigger point on the RWA outlook is that we expect to be bound over the medium term by standardized and standardized is going to always have a mutual to upwards pressure as we continue to grow these high-quality loans. So even though the RWA being at the 1.5-ish trillion dollars sooner than we expected is obviously good news, regardless of how much that may in the short term revert. Our job is going to be to continue to become more efficient to try and keep it there, just given the natural upward pressure of the standardized calculations. We can become more efficient in advance but we're unlikely to be bound by it in the medium term. So that's what we're focused on. I wouldn't take one, the -- $1.5 trillion and read through that will be continuing to decline from here on standardized. We'll be continuing to work hard to make sure that we can grow those loans that we lost but there have been [indiscernible] under standalone basis.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood, Marianne. That's very helpful. And then maybe just switching gears to the G-SIB surcharge. Clearly, the progress is price positively, again, down to the 3.5%. I was just wondering how you guys are thinking about establishing minimum capital ta
componenttext: Understood, Marianne. That's very helpful. And then maybe just switching gears to the G-SIB surcharge. Clearly, the progress is price positively, again, down to the 3.5%. I was just wondering how you guys are thinking about establishing minimum capital targets? I recognize you'll likely lay that out on Investor Day. I just wanted to get a better sense as to what methodology you are employing in terms of thinking about a management buffer and all the different binding constraints that you have to manage through day-to-day and thinking about the -- through-the-cycle target that you guys would like to manage to?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I miss something at the end, remind me. So in terms of how we think about buffers, just really conceptually, the firm manages and the board have set for the firm a risk appetite. That risk appetite has a number of features and capital depreciatio
componenttext: Okay. If I miss something at the end, remind me. So in terms of how we think about buffers, just really conceptually, the firm manages and the board have set for the firm a risk appetite. That risk appetite has a number of features and capital depreciation -- depletion and the stress environment is one of them. And so when we think about setting buffers, we think about it just broadly in the context of allowing ourselves enough room to absorb losses that are within our risk appetite and not have to take premature actions from a capital perspective. So but having said that, our buffer has been pretty consistent at the 50 basis point level for a reasonable period of time, and we'll update you on all of that at Investor Day. With respect to our target, it's a little bit more complicated than minimum regulated capital because as you say, we're bound potentially by multiple constraints and one of them maybe CCAR, plus -- well it is CCAR, I should say. Because as you know, the first 2 quarters of this year, our capital distribution plans have already been approved. And we haven't done CCAR, so this not any kind of prediction but it's not which is surprising you to know that it's unlikely that we will pay out 100% of our earnings in CCAR going forward. So we are on a path to continue to accrete capital that we would like to move up in our payout range. So given that we're still moving towards our 12% target and we will update you if any of that changes at Investor Day. We also, as you know, potentially going to understand whether or not the Fed changes any of the CCAR parameters and whether that has an impact. So at the moment, the best we know is that we can continue to accrete capital, albeit more slowly as we hope to move out in the payout range but we haven't done CCAR yet. And that set the rules, go change, so 12% is for now.

componenttext: Marianne, if I could just clarify your NII comment from the very beginning of the call. Do I understand correctly that the $2 billion of incremental NII that you've cited is just a function of the repricing dynamics as they move through your balance sheet rather -- or is there also I guess, a contribution from loan growth?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's both. So think about specific -- in a rate scenario, when you can pick whether you believe in market, whether you think the market is -- or whether you believe [indiscernible] and that -- it's going to be data dependent. So it's going to -- it will h
componenttext: It's both. So think about specific -- in a rate scenario, when you can pick whether you believe in market, whether you think the market is -- or whether you believe [indiscernible] and that -- it's going to be data dependent. So it's going to -- it will have a stated opinion on that. But because of the mix in our balance sheet in 2016 as well as our expectations for continued loan growth, we would expect mix to contribute about 1/2 of that and the 425 basis points about the next half because we are more sensitive to fund enterprise in the first 25 basis points and you can see that in our earnings and risk disclosures. So even if we see nothing else, so obviously, we believe and the market believes that you're going to see a couple of more hikes. That would be on average another 25 basis points and that would be incremental NII again.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, I would think about them in a somewhat similar directional way given that our balance sheet ended below $2.4 trillion. A little bit of it market delivered, a lot of it purchasable but we do intend to continue to govern deposits and extend loa
componenttext: I would say, I would think about them in a somewhat similar directional way given that our balance sheet ended below $2.4 trillion. A little bit of it market delivered, a lot of it purchasable but we do intend to continue to govern deposits and extend loans and while you're -- and portfolio loans as well. So while you will see some securities balances decline and the like, I would say again, net modest growth, not modest, and very lending driven.

componenttext: I just wanted to add a follow-up question on fixed income trading. That seems to be a little bit in contrast to the expectation that fixed income could pick up at higher rates. So if you could sort of talk to your thoughts on fixed income, I do notice that you did mention 1Q's off performing well, so may be that's part of it, too. But if you could help on that, that will be great.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So in terms of the impact of rates, obviously there was a lot of knowledge policy confusion broadly in the fourth quarter. The ECB and the [indiscernible] Fed was knowledge focused. So there's a lot of confusion but by the time the rate hike happene
componenttext: Okay. So in terms of the impact of rates, obviously there was a lot of knowledge policy confusion broadly in the fourth quarter. The ECB and the [indiscernible] Fed was knowledge focused. So there's a lot of confusion but by the time the rate hike happened, it was obviously pretty well understood. We did see strong activity or strong client activity relatively speaking on the back of that in the rates business, more so than necessarily about spreads. With respect to the fixed income business, we've always been very disciplined about how we think about the starting levels and the expenses in that business. We've managed that very carefully. The conversations have come down across the trading businesses and it wouldn't surprise you that some of that or a lot of that has been in fixed income. And our business is acted and protected. So...

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016

componenttextpreview: You've seen in fixed income -- we have a very good fixed income operation globally around the world. Rates themselves don't filter through fixed-rate indirectly. I think what Janet was talk about is that we have healthy economies and confident investors,
componenttext: You've seen in fixed income -- we have a very good fixed income operation globally around the world. Rates themselves don't filter through fixed-rate indirectly. I think what Janet was talk about is that we have healthy economies and confident investors, you have more volume and things like that. We do see a little bit of repricing taking place in the prime broker, repo, conduit and some of those things run through Fed. So that is going to take place as the world adjust to new -- all the new capital requirements. And obviously, there's always seasonality in the business, which we've experienced for the last decade.

componenttext: And then a follow-up question on your portfolio. You look like you can grow your residential loans by about $11 billion. headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it's about 60% jumbos, 40% agency or conventional performing. And it's the best execution business. When we look at the better economics between selling or fulfilling the mortgage, we'll generally choose the best of economics. But we also prefer t
componenttext: Yes. So it's about 60% jumbos, 40% agency or conventional performing. And it's the best execution business. When we look at the better economics between selling or fulfilling the mortgage, we'll generally choose the best of economics. But we also prefer the annuity nature of the NII, the lower servicing risk and a better capital efficiency. So it has been the case over the course of the last several quarters, that it has been the best execution to portfolio. There's mortgages and actually they're generating a nice return on equity.

componenttext: So we have had pretty big tax gains over the course of last and [indiscernible] much more to last quarter, because the last couple of years, most of those related to the fullest call it '03 through '08 tax periods when we were going through the financial crisis and so some of the matters were more complex and we took appropriate reserving decisions on that. There are many left at those very complicated matters ahead of us and so we wouldn't expect to see the same sort of size and tax benefit going forward as we'd seen in the past. But we had some of it this quarter. So we'll have a few and generally speaking, they are -- because of the nature of the reserving for tax, generally speaking, we take a conservative approach and the buyers are positive but it could be much more plus or minus zero at this point.

componenttext: So do I think it's plateaued? I think it remains incredibly competitive, particularly in costs, generally and particularly in the co-brand space. So plateaus at a very competitive level, I suppose. But in terms of -- I'm not going to talk about any specific names, actually Brian, in terms of the potential for repricing. It's an important part of our business and we're going to defend our business.

componenttext: If the regulators lift the dividend payout ratio and issue a CCAR to 40%, what -- would you guys consider lifting then your dividend payout ratio something closer to that?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a board decision and so neither have we received that guidance from the regulators nor have we done CCAR and have that discussion yet with the board, but we have generally said that the board likes to have the flexibility to increase dividends
componenttext: Well, it's a board decision and so neither have we received that guidance from the regulators nor have we done CCAR and have that discussion yet with the board, but we have generally said that the board likes to have the flexibility to increase dividends by the time. And we have had our dividends most recently for the act or close to that softback. So we would love that capacity and I would imagine that over time, it may be used but again, it is a board decision, not a management decision.

componenttext: So from -- we do have it in pro forma. And so first of all, I would say the following: right now, my understanding and if I'm wrong, forgive me, is that your stock balance sheet 2 years prior that would drive your G-SIBs 2 years forward.  But the reality, if you ask my opinion given that we're going to be reporting quarterly going forward and because of the likelihood that GSIB may or may not feature into CCAR, I think it's going to be less important necessarily what you are at any moment in time. But the way you're projecting to be will stay. So I suspect that we will get the benefit potentially a bit, not today, we haven't in our -- we disclosed our balance sheet but I think that it's going to need to be a little bit more dynamic going forward as it gets potentially into introducing a stress test. But I don't know that.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to JPMorgan Chase's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions]At this time, I would like to turn the call over to JPMorgan Chase's Chairman and CEO, Jamie Dimon; an
componenttext:
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to JPMorgan Chase's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions]
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to JPMorgan Chase's Chairman and CEO, Jamie Dimon; and Chief Financial Officer, Marianne Lake. Ms. Lake, please go ahead.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everybody. I'm going to take you through the earnings presentation, which is available on our website. Please refer to the disclaimer regarding forward-looking statements at the back of the presentation. Starting on Page 1. The fi
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everybody. I'm going to take you through the earnings presentation, which is available on our website. Please refer to the disclaimer regarding forward-looking statements at the back of the presentation. Starting on Page 1. The firm reported net income of $5.4 billion, EPS of $1.32 and a return on tangible common equity of 11% on $23.7 billion of revenue. Included in the results is legal expense of $400 million after tax for a range of matters, and we continue to put some issues behind us. This is reflected in a reduction of more than $1 billion to our reasonably possible loss estimate this quarter.
In addition, we recognized the benefit of a settlement reached of $300 million after tax, which related to monies owed to Washington Mutual in connection with a failed savings and loan institution. We're showing this on the page as legal-related and the benefit is recorded in revenue in corporate.
Much like we saw in the third quarter, the overall company's performance benefited from diversification across our businesses. We saw strong growth in consumer drivers, on the back of improvement in the U.S. economy, in large part generating core loan growth of 16% for the company. Global markets remained challenged across a number of fronts, leading to lower client activity and lower inventory. Against this backdrop, the CIB delivered solid performance across products. And in the quarter, we continued our trend of strong balance sheet, capital and expense discipline and exceeded targets.
Shifting to the full year's results, if you skip over Page 2, on Page 3. The firm earned record net income of $24.4 billion and record EPS of $6 a share and a return on tangible common equity of 13.5% on revenue of nearly $97 billion. Revenue was down 1% or $1.3 billion, driven by noncore items, most notably by business simplification in the investment bank and also in private equity. Adjusted, our underlying businesses were up modestly. We're very happy with our expense story for the year. We delivered adjusted expense of $56 billion, down $2.4 billion and a 2 percentage point decrease in adjusted overhead ratio. And while we did have a modest benefit from the strengthening dollar this year, we also self-funded incremental investments. Credit performance was strong, in line with our expectations, with net charge-offs at $4.1 billion, with obviously the biggest area of stress in wholesale being oil and gas, against which we built about $550 million of reserves this year, including $124 million this quarter. And as the outlook for oil has weakened, we would expect to see some additional reserve build in 2016 but prices would need to remain at this level for an extended period for them to be significant.
We also built $68 million of reserves in metals and mining, including $35 million this quarter. We're watching this sector closely and similarly, as commodity prices remain at current levels, we would expect some additional reserve builds but would not expect them to be significant. Finally, net capital distributions for the year were approximately $11 billion, including dividends of $1.72 a share. 
Turning to Page 4. Starting on the top left, overall, our average balance sheet is down $100 billion year-on-year and our spot balance sheet down over $200 billion, with, of course, the biggest driver being a reduction of approximately $200 billion of wholesale nonoperating deposits, ultimately reflected in lower cash balances. In addition, you can see notable reductions in all other balance sheet categories, except for loans, which reflects the 16% core loan growth we achieved. Some portion of the other wholesale balance reductions were purposeful and will be sticky, particularly the decrease in short-term wholesale funding balances. The remainder resulted from volatile markets and general deleveraging, driving risk off and lower inventory across products. As client demand for leverage grows, we will likely put some of that balance sheet back to work.
Moving to the right. The story on deposits continues to be a very positive one, as we delivered some incremental reductions of nonoperating balance while consistently growing retail and operating deposits. On the bottom left, overall, NII was up about $300 million, driving a 7 basis point improvement in NIM. The increase in NII reflects a mix shift to loans but also includes gains on certain securities and the impact of the rate move in December on this quarter's NII was not significant.
Looking forward to the first quarter. Expect firm NII and NIM to be flat to up slightly, on higher rates and mix, substantially offset by the absence of those security gains as well as normal seasonal day count. However, for the full year, with the December rate hike alone, so in a rate flat scenario, together with the loan growth that we have seen and expect, we would expect to deliver about $2 billion of incremental NII.
Perhaps the highlight of this page on the bottom right is that based upon the actions we've taken throughout the course of 2015, we believe that we have just reached the 3.5% Method 2 G-SIB bucket and that we are in or close to the 2% Method 1 G-SIB bucket. So the task ahead is to solidify this position, which we'll talk more about at Investor Day.
Turning to Page 5. We're ending the year well ahead of our capital targets, with the firm's Advanced Fully Phased-In CET1 ratio at 11.6% and our Standardized Fully Phased-In ratio at 11.7%. The improvement to both ratios was driven by net capital generation, along with an overall reduction in risk-weighted assets, with net loan growth being more than offset by lower market risk, reductions in derivatives as well as secured financing balances. And these delivered a more meaningful reduction under the standardized approach. But with reference to my earlier comments on redeploying balance sheet, a portion of this reduction will likely reverse in the near future.
Firm and bank SLR were at 6.5% and 6.6%, respectively. Finally, we returned $2.6 billion of net capital to shareholders this quarter, including $1 billion of net repurchases and common dividends of $0.44 a share.
Let's turn to Page 6 and Consumer & Community Banking. The combined consumer businesses generated $2.4 billion of net income on revenue of $11.2 billion and an ROE of 18% for the quarter. And full year expense was down by nearly $1 billion or half of our commitment if you adjust for legal and $150 million of incremental investments this year. Going forward, we'll look for opportunities to further reinvest. You can see headcount was down by 12,000 for the year and nearly 43,000 since 2012.
The fundamental business drivers remain strong. Year-over-year, average loans were up 11%, with core loans up 25% driven by mortgage, but with strength across products. Average deposits were up 10%. We added nearly 600,000 households and our active mobile customer base continues to grow, up 20% to roughly 23 million customers, the largest of the major U.S. banks.
Moving to Page 7, Consumer & Business Banking. CBB generated strong results for the quarter, with net income of $968 million and an ROE of 32%, on relatively flat revenue of $4.6 billion. Although NII was flat quarter-on-quarter, it was down 5% year-on-year on spread compression, largely offset by that 10% deposit growth. And excluding an $85 million gain on the sale of a branch, noninterest revenue was down 3% seasonally and up 4% year-on-year, driven by higher service fees and strong debit volume. We expect NII to show normal seasonal declines in the first quarter. Expense was down 3% year-on-year on lower headcount from branch efficiency. And additionally, client assets were up 2% and Business Banking average loan balance is up 6%.
Next, Mortgage Banking on Page 8. Overall net income was $266 million. Originations in the quarter were $23 billion, down seasonally and we continue to add high-quality loans to our balance sheet; $16 billion for the quarter and totaling $70 billion for the full year. Total revenue of $1.7 billion increased 8% sequentially, on strong loan growth as well as on higher MSR risk management. For the full year, our loan interest revenue was down relative to 2014 by $1.2 billion, broadly in line with our guidance and that downward trend will continue as servicing balances continue to decline, and as we expect production margins will compress in the smaller markets. We expect the decline in 2016 to be around $700 million.
Expense of $1.2 billion ticked up this quarter, related to exiting the OCC's consent order, but it was down 10% year-on-year as we continue to manage costs. Finally, on credit. Net charge-offs of 13 basis points reflects the quality of our portfolio.
Moving on to Page 9, Card, Commercial Solutions & Auto. Overall net income of $1.2 billion and an ROE of 24%. Revenue was $5 billion, up 10% year-on-year, driven principally by 2 nonrecurring items. The first was a loss in the prior year of over $200 million that related to noncore portfolio exits and a gain we saw this quarter of about $160 million on the IPO of Square. Adjusted, the revenue rate was 11.9% and in terms of core performance, business drivers were strong and growth offset the impact of co-brand renewals on noninterest revenues while driving growth in NII. Year-over-year, we saw growth of 12% in auto, loan and lease balances; 6% in cars sales volume; 3% in cars core loans as well as 12% and 14% in merchant processing volumes and transactions, respectively. Expense of $2.2 billion, flat quarter-on-quarter but up 4% year-on-year, reflected higher depreciation on auto lease growth. And we expect expense to be relatively flat into the first quarter as we continue to invest.
While on auto, 2015 set a record for new car sales, with strength in the fourth quarter continuing through December, when we gained nearly 40 basis points a share year-over-year, with the strength of our manufacturing partnerships driving growth. Finally on Credit, in auto, net charge-offs were 50 basis points and while higher, it was still below our long-term expectations. And in Card, the net charge-off rate was 242 basis points for the quarter, 251 for the year, and given our underwriting discipline, client selection and the improving economy, we expect net charge-offs to stay at these levels in 2016.
Now turning to Page 10 and the Corporate & Investment Bank. CIB reported net income of $1.7 billion on revenue of $7.1 billion and an ROE of 10%. In investment banking for the full year, we continue to rank #1 in global IDCs and #1 in North America and EMEA. In M&A, we maintained our #2 ranking and grew wallet share by 50 basis points. In ECM, we ranked #1 globally, up from #3 last year; and in DCM, we ranked #1 across high yield, high grades and loans.
Banking revenue for the quarter of $1.5 billion was down 11%, driven by lower debt underwriting fees. It was another outstanding performance in advisory fees, up 43% in the corporate third quarter in a market that was down 12%, largely driven by North America. Equity underwriting fees were down 4% in the market down 12%, with the U.S. remaining somewhat slow but a resurgence of large transactions in Europe and Asia, and debt underwriting fees were down 43% from a record last year where we saw an unprecedented number of large fee events.
Treasury Services revenue was flat quarter-on-quarter but down 4% year-on-year on lower deposit spreads. In markets, a number of factors contributed to a quiet fourth quarter overall across products. Investor risk appetite was significantly dampened by a series of market events and clients retrenched and de-risked early. With that backdrop, the market businesses delivered $3.6 billion in revenue, in line with our expectations and normal seasonal trends, with adjusted revenues down 16% sequentially and 1% year-on-year. In fixed income, rate markets were up, given U.S. and ECB monetary policy actions, offset by year-on-year declines in currencies and emerging markets as the strong dollar and emerging markets uncertainties persisted, as well as the commodities on reduced hedging and declines in credit, on all those themes plus a number of single name corporate events. Equities delivered solid results, flat excluding the exit of broker-dealer services last year, with strong performance in Europe being offset by lower deal flow in North America and Asia compared to a strong prior year.
With respect to the first quarter, reflecting low levels of client activity, we were light risk going into the year end and inventory was low. And so far, our trading businesses are performing well. But as you know, it is early and it's difficult to predict how the quarter will play out. Security Services revenue was $933 million, in line with guidance given the continued impact of lower emerging markets on asset-based fees. For the first quarter, expect revenue to be approximately $900 million, which includes seasonality. On credit, we saw a reserve build of $76 million, which included $63 million related to oil and gas. Finally, expense of $4.4 billion was down 20% year-on-year, mainly driven by lower legal. The comp-to-revenue ratio was 26% for the quarter and 30% for the full year.
Moving on to page 11 and the Commercial Bank. The Commercial Bank generated net income of $550 million on revenue of $1.8 billion and an ROE of 15%. Revenue was up sequentially, but relatively flat year-on-year, with NII up 3% on higher loan balances despite spread compression offset by lower IB revenue from a strong quarter last year. However, for the full year, it was a record for investment banking, with gross revenue of $2.2 billion, up 10% from 2014. Expense of $750 million included $50 million of impairments on leased corporate aircraft, on the reassessment of residual values. The remaining balance sheet value of this portfolio is modest. We saw record average loan balances of $166 billion, up 14% year-on-year, with growth in Commercial Real Estate of 17% exceeding the industry as we continue to invest in its business and gain share. And C&I, loans were up 11%, largely driven by Corporate Client Banking on the back of several large transactions.
Finally, credit performance of the portfolio does remain strong with only 4 basis points of net charge-offs. However, we did add $100 million to reserves, $60 million of which relates to oil and gas and $26 million for metals and mining.
Moving on to Page 12, Asset Management. Asset Management reported net income of $500 million, with a 27% pretax margin and 21% ROE, on revenue of $3 billion, down 5% year-on-year, driven by lower performance fees in alternatives. Expense of $2.2 billion was also down 5% year-on-year, roughly equally explained by lower performance fee-driven compensation as well as a benefit from refining the value of a health scale asset. Assets under management of $1.7 trillion and client assets of $2.4 trillion were down 1% and 2% year-over-year, respectively. We saw mixed flows in the fourth quarter resulting in long-term net outflows of $9 billion, with solid inflows in Equity being more than offset by weakness in Fixed Income and the loss of select mandates. However, we had strong long-term investment performance, with 80% of mutual fund AUM ranked in the first or second quartiles over 5 years, which should be supportive of future flow. And for the full year, we had positive long term inflows of $16 billion. In Lending, we had record balances $110 billion, up 7% year-on-year, driven by both mortgage as well as traditional loans.
Turning to page 13 and Corporate. Treasury & CIO reported net income of $138 million for the quarter. Included in this result, there's a pretax benefit of $178 million relating to certain securities held at a discount that were called at par and this was in our NII. Other Corporate net income of $84 million included a net benefit of $60 million after tax for the legal related matters we discussed earlier, as well as a contribution to our foundation this quarter of $150 million pretax.
Turning to page 14. I've given you some guidance throughout the presentation and this page is for your reference. Obviously, when we get to Investor Day, we will give you a comprehensive outlook for each of our businesses for the year. So in summary, a solid quarter and a record for the full year, both in terms of net income and EPS, which even on higher capital, translates to a good return on tangible common equity of 13.5%. We exceeded our targets on expense management, generating positive operating leverage and improving our adjusted overhead ratio by 2 percentage points. Another strong core loan growth of 16%, materially changed the mix of our deposit base, including growing retail deposits at 10% and made meaningful progress on our balance sheet, our [indiscernible] surcharge and capital levels. With that, operator, we'll take Q&A.

componenttextpreview: So curious about whether or not you all have seen the stress we've seen in some of the credit and equity markets and some of the volatility impacting M&A velocity, appetite amongst boards and C suites broadly in your conversations and throughout the IB?
componenttext: So curious about whether or not you all have seen the stress we've seen in some of the credit and equity markets and some of the volatility impacting M&A velocity, appetite amongst boards and C suites broadly in your conversations and throughout the IB?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So -- I mean, again, I would say that the pipeline coming into 2016 in M&A was good, solid, up and back. Obviously, volatility can dampen the confidence of Boards and CEOs. Dialogues are pretty active and we think the types of deals that we'll see in 2016
componenttext: So -- I mean, again, I would say that the pipeline coming into 2016 in M&A was good, solid, up and back. Obviously, volatility can dampen the confidence of Boards and CEOs. Dialogues are pretty active and we think the types of deals that we'll see in 2016 will look different. But I think in the first couple of weeks, it's not been particularly strong and we do need to see some of the stability come back, I think, for us to really see that conversion start to pick up.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just by different -- is that a reference to size or is that -- can you be a bit more specific on what you mean?
componenttext: And just by different -- is that a reference to size or is that -- can you be a bit more specific on what you mean?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Size. Yes, less megadeals, more mid-sized deals, more cross-borders but it's a little bit different actually, more deal count, less big, megadeals could be very constructive for revenue but we are likely to see it be a little bit different in 2016. But ho
componenttext: Size. Yes, less megadeals, more mid-sized deals, more cross-borders but it's a little bit different actually, more deal count, less big, megadeals could be very constructive for revenue but we are likely to see it be a little bit different in 2016. But honestly, the pipeline is good and -- yes, you have to be -- North America will be a tough comp. It was very strong in 2015, but Europe could be very constructive.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Terrific. Helpful. And then you referenced energy prices staying this low would lead to a significant reserve build, do you expect in your energy book. Can you maybe give a little bit more color around that? How would you define significant and how long w
componenttext: Terrific. Helpful. And then you referenced energy prices staying this low would lead to a significant reserve build, do you expect in your energy book. Can you maybe give a little bit more color around that? How would you define significant and how long would oil need to stay down here in order to see some of that reserve action?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the way we do our results, this is just for context, I think it's important -- it's obviously, the oil price outlook is important and instructive and it's very clearly going to drive how we think about probabilities of default and loss, given defa
componenttext: Yes. So the way we do our results, this is just for context, I think it's important -- it's obviously, the oil price outlook is important and instructive and it's very clearly going to drive how we think about probabilities of default and loss, given default of certain of our customers, but I think it's also the case just for context to know that it is very name-by-name specific and specific conditions at clients matter greatly. And so when we do these estimates, they are directionally correct and order of magnitude correct. But that's just the context. Oil, we said last quarter, if oil reached $30 a barrel and here we are, and stayed there for call it, 18 months, you could expect to see reserve builds of up to $750 million and that assessment hasn't fundamentally changed. So it is not the current market expectation that oil will flat line. It is -- the expectation right now that there will be a modest recovery. Based upon that, we would expect to take some additional reserves but for them to be more modest, less significant, but that's kind of the range. If oil's at $30 and stays here for a long time, up to $750 million.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Mike Mayo with CLSA.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Mike Mayo with CLSA.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow-up on the oil and gas question. It just seems as though $124 million in additional provisions for oil and gas could be low, at least based on the 1-year forward prices for oil, which are still in the 30s. Inside -- my question is for Ja
componenttext: I wanted to follow-up on the oil and gas question. It just seems as though $124 million in additional provisions for oil and gas could be low, at least based on the 1-year forward prices for oil, which are still in the 30s. Inside -- my question is for Jamie. As you look back, how does the oil and gas situation today compare to prior periods of stress. We have 2002. We had the TMT meltdown when you were at Bank One. You reduced the lines of credit. You got ahead of that early. In 2007, you weren't exactly at the start but then you adjusted and you said, "Hey, this is a big issue." And now we have oil and gas, which could be another industry-specific stress and you're only taking additional provisions of $124 million. Is that going to be enough? And 1-year from now, are you going to look back and say, "Oops, we didn't get ahead of this enough."

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, first I'd say, we try to be very conservative, always, and so we're not trying to put up as little as possible. Me, I would put up more if I could but the accounting rules dictate what you can do and these are baskets of -- the real risk is in pr
componenttext: I think, first I'd say, we try to be very conservative, always, and so we're not trying to put up as little as possible. Me, I would put up more if I could but the accounting rules dictate what you can do and these are baskets of -- the real risk is in producing wells, cash flows are down. Surprisingly the cost for them to get the oil off the ground has also dropped dramatically. And probably much more than most of us would have expected. So you take these producing wells, you take the cash flows, you discount -- you discount it at 8% or 9%, you lend against it. And so these are our forecasts and this is -- our energy book -- in that large relative to JPMorgan Chase, we're not worried about the big oil companies. These are mostly smaller ones that were -- that your company's reserve increases on.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd also say, Mike, just...
componenttext: I'd also say, Mike, just...

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the total curve is -- the end of the year for 2016 is like 41, 42 or something like that.
componenttext: And the total curve is -- the end of the year for 2016 is like 41, 42 or something like that.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. 40-ish. So, Mike, the other thing to know about sort of profile of reserves, 3 things. The first is it's not linear. So not just that the oil price decline and the decline in the forward curve that we saw towards -- into December and to the end of th
componenttext: Yes. 40-ish. So, Mike, the other thing to know about sort of profile of reserves, 3 things. The first is it's not linear. So not just that the oil price decline and the decline in the forward curve that we saw towards -- into December and to the end of the year, that's the impact it had on our reserves. It's fallen significantly in the first 2 quarters. That was not a knowable condition and we can't reserve for that at the end of the year. That's why we said, we would expect to take some more reserve increases in the next couple of quarters. But again, it's the main specific thing and lots of other conditions at clients matter including their hedging, their cash flows, their level of security, all those things.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how do you use CDS to help protect yourself on that portfolio?
componenttext: And how do you use CDS to help protect yourself on that portfolio?

componenttextpreview: We don't.
componenttext: We don't.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, you don't? And then the last follow-up, do you intend to keep lending to the oil and gas companies as they run into problems? On the one hand, you've had the risk of throwing good money after bad. On the other hand, if you stop lending as much and y
componenttext: Okay, you don't? And then the last follow-up, do you intend to keep lending to the oil and gas companies as they run into problems? On the one hand, you've had the risk of throwing good money after bad. On the other hand, if you stop lending as much and you have the high-yield market retreating and you have private equity firms retreating, maybe it becomes a liquidity crisis for some of the oil companies. So which is it? Do you lend more or less to the oil and gas sector?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, the oil folks have been surprisingly resilient. Remember, these are asset-backed loans. So a bankruptcy doesn't necessarily mean your loan is bad, so you have to be a little bit careful. And it's also -- Mike, it's philosophical thing. A ban
componenttext: First of all, the oil folks have been surprisingly resilient. Remember, these are asset-backed loans. So a bankruptcy doesn't necessarily mean your loan is bad, so you have to be a little bit careful. And it's also -- Mike, it's philosophical thing. A bank is supposed to be there for clients in good times and bad times. So it's not a trading market where you try to support clients. So then -- we can responsibly support clients, we're going to and we lose a little bit more money because -- so be it. And we've done that around the world. We did it in '07 and '08 and '09 and we try to do it responsibly. If banks just completely pullout of markets every time something gets volatile and scary, you'll be sinking companies left and right.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marianne, I was wondering if you could remind us where you are on your expense reduction targets in the Consumer and the Investment bank and how does that translate to some thoughts about the expected trajectory of total -- from what expenses for this yea
componenttext: Marianne, I was wondering if you could remind us where you are on your expense reduction targets in the Consumer and the Investment bank and how does that translate to some thoughts about the expected trajectory of total -- from what expenses for this year?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me just deal with where we are against our targets. So the most notable targets were $2 billion in the Consumer businesses in '17 versus '14 and $2.8 billion in CIB in '17 versus '14. You probably heard my comment but to clarify, on an apples-
componenttext: Yes. So let me just deal with where we are against our targets. So the most notable targets were $2 billion in the Consumer businesses in '17 versus '14 and $2.8 billion in CIB in '17 versus '14. You probably heard my comment but to clarify, on an apples-to-apples basis, we're half way through on Consumer, we've done $1 billion this year. You don't see that 100% translate into the results partly because of legal expense, which is not something that we particularly can predict and hopefully won't be there forever. Also because we intentionally decisioned in 2015, in the fourth quarter in particular, momentaly to increase our investments in the Consumer businesses by $150 million. So we've achieved the $1 billion. We chose to reinvest a portion of it. Another $1 billion, we're on track for. We will potentially reinvest some of that, too and Gordon, and we will talk to you about the basis for that at Investor Day. On the $2.8 billion in CIB, we're $1.3 billion through at the end of the year, and we talked before about the fact that the first $1.3 billion is largely on business simplification. We've had the revenue decline. We need to have the expense decline, and we've worked hard to deliver that and we have. The next chunk is to do with technology and operations and infrastructure and organization and it's harder. And so we will continue with them on track to deliver it. But it's going to be a job through 2016 into 2017.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how does that all net into an outlook for this year, if you're willing to give us some thoughts on that?
componenttext: And how does that all net into an outlook for this year, if you're willing to give us some thoughts on that?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can you some thoughts that won't totally satisfy you, which is our core expenses will continue to trend down on the back of delivering against them. But we will make investment decisions that we think are good for the company, accretive for shareho
componenttext: Yes, I can you some thoughts that won't totally satisfy you, which is our core expenses will continue to trend down on the back of delivering against them. But we will make investment decisions that we think are good for the company, accretive for shareholders. That will  respend some of that money. And so we'll give you that shrink and grow at Investor Day.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk to us a little bit about the benefits from rates as they come through. Obviously, your commentary that NII will be even flattish in the first quarter adjusted for day count and even with some securities gains in the numbe
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk to us a little bit about the benefits from rates as they come through. Obviously, your commentary that NII will be even flattish in the first quarter adjusted for day count and even with some securities gains in the numbers this quarter, presumes that's a nice helper from that first move. And you guys are really conservative on your deposit beta thoughts when you talked about them previously. I know probably haven't seen much change yet. But how are you expecting to deposit pay for the act? And has there been any change to your modeling expectations about what might come through as we get through the first couple of hikes?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So  -- just on NII, yes, we are seeing embedded in that sort of NII flat to up slightly, we are seeing a nice lift associated with the rate hike in December across businesses as well as the continued benefit of the mix towards loans in our balance sheet.
componenttext: So  -- just on NII, yes, we are seeing embedded in that sort of NII flat to up slightly, we are seeing a nice lift associated with the rate hike in December across businesses as well as the continued benefit of the mix towards loans in our balance sheet. But we were flatter in our NII this quarter by $178 million on securities gains in CIO. So that's going to mean the comparison is challenging and then day count is obviously seasonal. So that's the dynamic. We are seeing the rate benefit. We do expect to see it, as I said, in my remarks for the full year. Look, we think we are appropriately conservative on deposit reserves. It is not -- it is way too early to have any idea but that's really nothing, hasn't moved yet. And so our job and what we are doing is paying very close attention to the competitive landscape and these deposits that we're talking about, that have the high basis are valuable deposits with valuable clients for us and we want to be competitive and pay fair rates. But it's so early in the movie that we haven't changed much in our modeling assumptions.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, my second question, if I can ask an x-energy credit question. A lot of concerns that we're going to get into some type of broader deterioration of which your number showed no signs of heading towards. What are you looking for? Are you seeing any sig
componenttext: Okay, my second question, if I can ask an x-energy credit question. A lot of concerns that we're going to get into some type of broader deterioration of which your number showed no signs of heading towards. What are you looking for? Are you seeing any signals of x-energy changes in either delinquencies or watch trends? And are you still comfortable with kind of that low 4s type of charge of expectation that you guys had talked about previously.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So energy, metals and mining, we're watching very closely, industries that kind of -- could have knock on effects like industrials and transportation. But we're not seeing anything broadly in our portfolio right now. We're just watching very closely, whic
componenttext: So energy, metals and mining, we're watching very closely, industries that kind of -- could have knock on effects like industrials and transportation. But we're not seeing anything broadly in our portfolio right now. We're just watching very closely, which is why -- now obviously, you can take our reserve builds number and you can say it's almost essentially all made up of oil and gas, and metals and mining. And behind the scenes, we've had upgrades and downgrades of a number of other different companies across sectors but nothing particularly thematic yet. But we're watching.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now I need to point out that Credit Card, Commercial Bank, Middle Market, Large Corporate Credit is good as it's ever been. So obviously, it's going to get a little bit worse. I wouldn't call it a cycle per se. If you have a recession, you will see a norm
componenttext: Now I need to point out that Credit Card, Commercial Bank, Middle Market, Large Corporate Credit is good as it's ever been. So obviously, it's going to get a little bit worse. I wouldn't call it a cycle per se. If you have a recession, you will see a normal cyclical increase in all of those losses. We're not forecasting recession. We think that the U.S. economy looks pretty good at this point.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016

componenttext: Based on that, with the obvious caveat of what happens if oil prices and energy over the course of the near future, yes, we still expect our charge-off to be relatively low.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think you talked about some of this Marianne in terms of the methods you used to do surcharge now estimated at 3.5. I'm just curious. I think if the numbers are right, you took down [indiscernible] and those are about $3.4 trillion, $21 billion in Le
componenttext: So I think you talked about some of this Marianne in terms of the methods you used to do surcharge now estimated at 3.5. I'm just curious. I think if the numbers are right, you took down [indiscernible] and those are about $3.4 trillion, $21 billion in Level 3 assets, $50 billion in non-op deposits. You said that you don't want to be an outlier so you're whittling that down. I'm curious of the driving force behind it. What kind of revenue give up there is in such a move because we like it and thoughts on the go forward.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So look, we talked about achieving 4% last quarter I think and -- for disclosure we were quite close to 3.5. At that point, it becomes increasingly compelling to want to look at the margin or what you could do to get within the bucket and so that is
componenttext: Yes. So look, we talked about achieving 4% last quarter I think and -- for disclosure we were quite close to 3.5. At that point, it becomes increasingly compelling to want to look at the margin or what you could do to get within the bucket and so that is what we did in the fourth quarter is spent time really focusing on getting to that achievable boundary, which we thought at that point it was. And remember, it's not -- nothing in the year that we started the year thinking we would exit $100 billion of nonoperating deposit and while that's still there could be some volatility in that number, of course. We've almost doubled that or doubled that, in fact. So we got some wind to our backs in doing it. It's also the case that when you get the entire business and company attuned to the sense of urgency and desire to want to be increasingly efficient in this way, that, at the margin in our 100 different things, little benefit the crew. So the correct, about 3.5 -- it were just inside 3.5% bucket as best we estimated. It's not as much important whether we're basis points or surcharge points below or above. It's much more what we do now to get safely in the bucket and that's going to still take work. So that's why, we'll obviously talk to you more about this at Investor Day. In terms of the give up from an economic perspective, we wouldn't have done it at any cost. We have done it because we think it is important to do, because we think it's going to be constructive for the company and because the revenue give ups were not significant, but they weren't zero either. But to be able to reduce a constraint that it is in one way or another likely to bind us, or in multiple ways, in fact, likely to bind us, it was a I think a very good trade.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was done effectively client by client. Make sure we're trying to do the right thing for our clients, not just trimming our balance sheet down and hurting people.
componenttext: It was done effectively client by client. Make sure we're trying to do the right thing for our clients, not just trimming our balance sheet down and hurting people.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. I just have one quick follow-up on Ken's last question. If 2/3 of the economy is consumer lag, you look at all your early stage delinquencies like Ken said, and Jamie to your comments, things look okay. I hate putting words in your mouth but
componenttext: Fair enough. I just have one quick follow-up on Ken's last question. If 2/3 of the economy is consumer lag, you look at all your early stage delinquencies like Ken said, and Jamie to your comments, things look okay. I hate putting words in your mouth but what do you think the disconnect then is between what's going on in the markets versus what's going on in the trends in your business, both in terms of growth and forward-looking credit looks?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The U.S. economy has been chugging along at 2% to 2.5% growth for the better part of 5 years now. In the last few years it's created 5 million jobs and when you look at the actual household formation, car sales, wage, people working, it still looks okay.
componenttext: The U.S. economy has been chugging along at 2% to 2.5% growth for the better part of 5 years now. In the last few years it's created 5 million jobs and when you look at the actual household formation, car sales, wage, people working, it still looks okay. Corporate credit is quite good. Small business formation is not back to where it was but it's quite good. Household formation is going up. So obviously, market turmoil, we all look at it every day but I'm not sure if most of the 143 million Americans look at it that much who have jobs. And you have a big change in the world out there. People are getting adjusting to China's slowing down. You have commodity prices go down like that, there are big winners and losers, the oil companies are losers, consumers benefit. Brazil gets hurt. India benefits. South Korea benefits, Japan benefits and those kind of cause turbulent waters. And hopefully, this will all settle down and it's not the beginning of something really bad.
