headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The disclosure on oil and gas is really helpful and I was wondering if you could just walk through something similar on metals and mining. So you gave us the I think you said $68 million of full year reserve build, and you gave us the nonsignificant, if t
componenttext: The disclosure on oil and gas is really helpful and I was wondering if you could just walk through something similar on metals and mining. So you gave us the I think you said $68 million of full year reserve build, and you gave us the nonsignificant, if things stay where they are. Can you give us the balance and then is there a comparable $500 million to $750 million stress test for oil and gas or stress case? Is there a comparable, what is the stress case if broader commodities of metals and mining comes out worse?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So our total reserves on balance sheet for metals and mining, not withstanding we built 60-odd million dollars this year is over $200 million. So the coverage ratio is pretty good. The exposure is about -- I haven't got a precise number in front of
componenttext: Okay. So our total reserves on balance sheet for metals and mining, not withstanding we built 60-odd million dollars this year is over $200 million. So the coverage ratio is pretty good. The exposure is about -- I haven't got a precise number in front of me, about 1/3 the size of our exposure to oil and gas so that's 2% of our overall wholesale credit exposure. So considerably more modest, which is why if energy prices and general commodities weakness and stress stays where it is right now, even for an extended period, we would think that the incremental reserves will be considerably more modest.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And it's also -- that one is mostly name by name. It's not big asset base reserves. It just means to be big corporate credits name by name.
componenttext: And it's also -- that one is mostly name by name. It's not big asset base reserves. It just means to be big corporate credits name by name.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so both oil and gas and metals and mining in our portfolio, our oil and gas is close to 60% investment grade; metals and mining, about 1/2.
componenttext: And so both oil and gas and metals and mining in our portfolio, our oil and gas is close to 60% investment grade; metals and mining, about 1/2.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on, I guess staying with Credit on home equities and the whole issue of recast from interest only to amortizing. Can you kind of lay out how it's progressed relative to your expectations so far, and also remind us how big the allocation of the re
componenttext: And then on, I guess staying with Credit on home equities and the whole issue of recast from interest only to amortizing. Can you kind of lay out how it's progressed relative to your expectations so far, and also remind us how big the allocation of the reserve is against that? And I guess not to lead the witness but is that an area where things are trending early days better than expected and could provide some buffer against maybe anything else that happens on the C&I side?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so with respect to home equity recast, I mean remember the majority of the problematic home equity underwriting was 2005 through '08. So here we are at the beginning '16, with the sort of pig still in the python. But we're monitoring it closely, and
componenttext: Yes, so with respect to home equity recast, I mean remember the majority of the problematic home equity underwriting was 2005 through '08. So here we are at the beginning '16, with the sort of pig still in the python. But we're monitoring it closely, and we have some recasts that have happened. Obviously, interest rates are low. Home price appreciation on the other hand [indiscernible] so there are puts and takes. We've been monitoring it. I would say at the margin or more than at the margin at early stage is coming in better than we had modeled and remember, from an incurred loss perspective, we would consider these recast risks to be largely incurred. So we try to reserve them to the best of our ability. So we felt good about our reserve, but I think we've disclosed them. But so far from a performance perspective, I would say slightly better than our models, but we continue to monitor it because it's still relatively early.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes of the line of Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes of the line of Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marianne, I know that the Basel Committee put out their fundamental review of the trading book proposal this morning. So clearly, no one's really had time to go through it in detail. However I'm sure you have already gone through the prior proposal and do
componenttext: Marianne, I know that the Basel Committee put out their fundamental review of the trading book proposal this morning. So clearly, no one's really had time to go through it in detail. However I'm sure you have already gone through the prior proposal and done the QIS for the last couple of years. The proposal's better than what had been -- the ruling is better than what the proposal -- most recent one had been. Just wanted to get a sense from you as to how you can manage to this 2019 implementation time frame? Are there things set in motion already? Or is this something that you would start from here? And if you could just give us some broad strokes on how you think about overall impact, that would be helpful.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So obviously, you'll forgive me because we've been on call since it came out but yes, we have been working on this for years. The problem with this particular rule is that as you stated, based upon the 4 QISs that were done, there were some -- I woul
componenttext: Yes. So obviously, you'll forgive me because we've been on call since it came out but yes, we have been working on this for years. The problem with this particular rule is that as you stated, based upon the 4 QISs that were done, there were some -- I would characterize significant challenges with respect to the rules as written and we were expecting there to be a number of meaningful changes and there have been; in many cases, meaningful improvements. But it's very technical and there's been a lot of changes so we need to filter it to figure out net-net everything. Although it is clear that net-net, despite the fact that the stated intention of the committee wasn't necessarily to increase market risk capital across the industry. It will be higher. But by how much, it's really going to need to be sifted through and for that same reason, for both those same reasons -- I'm sorry, for the reason that the rule has not been stable and there have been significant questions, many of which have been either addressed or partially addressed and many, I guess that have not. It would have been premature to have taken any actions in advance of figuring out where this has landed and as you know, the period sort of complies 3 years. So it's more of start from here to figure out how to manage with this after we sifted through the details. So I wish I would -- were able to give a little bit more of a detailed answer but we're going to need to take the time to go through it.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. I totally understand that and I guess my basic question is, there's -- you can take action as opposed to just deal with what the current decision would be for you.  There are actions that you can take to reduce the impact?
componenttext: Right. I totally understand that and I guess my basic question is, there's -- you can take action as opposed to just deal with what the current decision would be for you.  There are actions that you can take to reduce the impact?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well then, there are always actions that we can take to reduce the impact. And so -- we have to think about them in the context of our overall capital optimization program. And again, if there are -- if some of the things that we host -- and I honestly, I
componenttext: Well then, there are always actions that we can take to reduce the impact. And so -- we have to think about them in the context of our overall capital optimization program. And again, if there are -- if some of the things that we host -- and I honestly, I've been on call since it came out but some of the things that we hope were going to be addressed have not. They could have had or may have meaningful impact on specific types of activity. And we will have to react accordingly. And yes, we will take actions if that's the right answer. I wish I could give you more details but we just need to go through it.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Chubak with Nomura.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Chubak with Nomura.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I had a couple of questions on capital. The first relates to the RWA progress, which did surprise positively in the year by about $50 billion ahead of expectations. And I was just hoping you can give a better sense, Marianne, just given some of your pr
componenttext: So I had a couple of questions on capital. The first relates to the RWA progress, which did surprise positively in the year by about $50 billion ahead of expectations. And I was just hoping you can give a better sense, Marianne, just given some of your prepared remarks as to how much of that incremental $50 billion reduction was a function of more proactive mitigation efforts, maybe even tied to the recent mitigation efforts that you guys had talked about, which should presumably remain in the run rate versus balance sheet shrinkage that maybe due to the risk/loss environment that we're experiencing today.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So -- I would say that based upon sort of fourth quarter balance sheet, given that market risk was a driver, given that balance sheet levels were a driver particularly on standardized. We could give back on standardized as much as 10, 20 bps of capit
componenttext: Yes. So -- I would say that based upon sort of fourth quarter balance sheet, given that market risk was a driver, given that balance sheet levels were a driver particularly on standardized. We could give back on standardized as much as 10, 20 bps of capital -- of the 10.7% capital accretion. But the bigger point on the RWA outlook is that we expect to be bound over the medium term by standardized, and standardized is going to always have a mutual to upwards pressure as we continue to grow these high-quality loans. So even though the RWA, being at the 1.5-ish trillion dollars sooner than we expected is obviously good news, regardless of how much of that may in the short term revert. Our job is going to be to continue to become more efficient to try and keep it there, just given the natural upward pressure of the standardized calculations. We can become more efficient in advance but we're unlikely to be bound by it in the medium term. So that's what we're focused on. I wouldn't take one, the -- $1.5 trillion and read through that will be continuing to decline from here on standardized. We'll be continuing to work hard to make sure that we can grow those loans that we love but there have punitive risk rates under a standardized basis.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood, Marianne. That's very helpful. And then maybe just switching gears to the G-SIB surcharge. Clearly, the progress surprised positively, again, down to the 3.5%. I was just wondering how you guys are thinking about establishing minimum capital t
componenttext: Understood, Marianne. That's very helpful. And then maybe just switching gears to the G-SIB surcharge. Clearly, the progress surprised positively, again, down to the 3.5%. I was just wondering how you guys are thinking about establishing minimum capital targets? I recognize you'll likely lay that out on Investor Day. I just wanted to get a better sense as to what methodology you are employing in terms of thinking about a management buffer and all the different binding constraints that you have to manage through day-to-day and thinking about the -- through-the-cycle target that you guys would like to manage to?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I miss something at the end, remind me. So in terms of how we think about buffers, just really conceptually, the firm manages and the Board have set for the firm a risk appetite. That risk appetite has a number of features and capital depreciatio
componenttext: Okay. If I miss something at the end, remind me. So in terms of how we think about buffers, just really conceptually, the firm manages and the Board have set for the firm a risk appetite. That risk appetite has a number of features and capital depreciation -- depletion in a stress environment is one of them. And so when we think about setting buffers, we think about it just broadly in the context of allowing ourselves enough room to absorb losses that are within our risk appetite and not have to take premature actions from a capital perspective. So -- but having said that, our buffer has been pretty consistent at the 50 basis point level for a reasonable period of time, and we'll update you on all of that at Investor Day. With respect to our target, it's a little bit more complicated than minimum regulatory capital because as you say, we're bound potentially by multiple constraints and one of them maybe CCAR, plus -- well it is CCAR, I should say. Because as you know, the first 2 quarters of this year, our capital distribution plans have already been approved. And we haven't done CCAR, so this not any kind of prediction but it's not going to surprise you to know that it's unlikely that we will pay out 100% of our earnings in CCAR going forward. So we are on a path to continue to accrete capital, though we would like to move up in our payout range. So given that, we're still moving towards our 12% target and we will update you if any of that changes at Investor Day. We also, as you know, potentially going to understand whether or not the Fed changes any of the CCAR parameters and whether that has an impact. So at the moment, the best we know is that we can continue to accrete capital, albeit more slowly as we hope to move up in the payout range but we haven't done CCAR yet. And that's if the rules don't change, so 12% it is for now.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Wasserstrom with Guggenheim Securities.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marianne, if I could just clarify your NII comment from the very beginning of the call. Do I understand correctly that the $2 billion of incremental NII that you've cited is just a function of the repricing dynamics as they move through your balance sheet
componenttext: Marianne, if I could just clarify your NII comment from the very beginning of the call. Do I understand correctly that the $2 billion of incremental NII that you've cited is just a function of the repricing dynamics as they move through your balance sheet rather -- or is there also I guess, a contribution from loan growth?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's both. So think about in a rate set scenario, when you can pick whether you believe in market, whether you think the market is -- or whether you believe [indiscernible] docs and I think it's going to be data dependent. So we're not going to have a sta
componenttext: It's both. So think about in a rate set scenario, when you can pick whether you believe in market, whether you think the market is -- or whether you believe [indiscernible] docs and I think it's going to be data dependent. So we're not going to have a stated opinion on that. But because of the mix in our balance sheet in 2016 as well as our expectations for continued loan growth, we would expect mix to contribute about 1/2 of that and the first 25 basis points about the next half because we are more sensitive to the front end of rates in the first 25 basis points and you can see that in our earnings and risk disclosures. So even if we see nothing else. Now obviously, we believe and the market believes that you're going to see a couple of more hikes. That would be on average another 25 basis points and that would be incremental NII again.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And so -- I know we just touched on RWAs but how do you suggest we think about GAAP assets for this year?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, I would think about them in a somewhat similar directional way given that our balance sheet ended below $2.4 trillion. A little bit of it market delivered, a lot of it purposeful. But we do intend to continue to gather deposits and extend loa
componenttext: I would say, I would think about them in a somewhat similar directional way given that our balance sheet ended below $2.4 trillion. A little bit of it market delivered, a lot of it purposeful. But we do intend to continue to gather deposits and extend loans and while you're -- and portfolio loans as well. So while you will see some securities balances decline and the like, I would say again, net modest growth, but modest, and very lending driven.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to add a follow-up question on fixed income trading. I think Dan Pinto talked about benefits from higher rates and so I guess number one, I wanted to see if you had any thoughts on that, have you seen initial benefits to spreads in the fixed
componenttext: I just wanted to add a follow-up question on fixed income trading. I think Dan Pinto talked about benefits from higher rates and so I guess number one, I wanted to see if you had any thoughts on that, have you seen initial benefits to spreads in the fixed trading market, with the first rate hike. And in contrast, you have had a couple of competitors announced or at least reported that they're cutting headcount. That seems to be a little bit in contrast to the expectation that fixed income could pick up at higher rates. So if you could sort of talk to your thoughts on fixed income, I do notice that you did mention 1Q's off to performing well, so maybe that's part of it, too. But if you could help on that, that will be great.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So in terms of the impact of rates, obviously there was a lot of monetary policy confusion broadly in the fourth quarter. The ECB underwhelmed the Feds [indiscernible]. So there was a lot of confusion but by the time the rate hike happened, it was o
componenttext: Okay. So in terms of the impact of rates, obviously there was a lot of monetary policy confusion broadly in the fourth quarter. The ECB underwhelmed the Feds [indiscernible]. So there was a lot of confusion but by the time the rate hike happened, it was obviously pretty well understood. We did see strong activity or strong client activity relatively speaking on the back of that in the rates business, more so than necessarily about spreads. With respect to the fixed income business, we've always been very disciplined about how we think about the starting levels and the expenses in that business. We've managed it very carefully. The compensation have come down across the trading businesses and it wouldn't surprise you that some of that or a lot of that has been in fixed income. And our business is active and productive. So...

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. So you still pretty feel comfortable with your outlook that things could improve and market share gain potentials as competitors pull back?
componenttext: All right. So you still pretty feel comfortable with your outlook that things could improve and market share gain potentials as competitors pull back?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've seen in fixed income -- we have a very good fixed income operation globally around the world. Rates themselves don't filter through fixed-rate indirectly. I think what Danny was talking about is that when you have healthy economies and confident in
componenttext: You've seen in fixed income -- we have a very good fixed income operation globally around the world. Rates themselves don't filter through fixed-rate indirectly. I think what Danny was talking about is that when you have healthy economies and confident investors, you have more volume and things like that. We do see a little bit of repricing taking place in the prime broker, repo, conduit and some of those things run through Fed. So that is going to take place as the world adjust to new -- all the new capital requirements. And obviously, there's a lot of seasonality in the business, which we've experienced for the last decade.

componenttext: Jamie, to follow up on your comments about maybe some better pricing in prime brokerage and repo because of the capital requirements or requiring you guys to raise prices, could you expand upon that? componenttextpreview: We know that you implemented a new disclosure form in the Mortgage Backing space TRID. Did I have any -- I mean you guys had very good Mortgage Backing results. Did that have any impact whatsoever on your operations in the mortgage-backed?
componenttext: We know that you implemented a new disclosure form in the Mortgage Backing space TRID. Did I have any -- I mean you guys had very good Mortgage Backing results. Did that have any impact whatsoever on your operations in the mortgage-backed?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So yes. Obviously, I think if you add up TRID plus other servicing rules, print them out, put them on the floor and stand them next to me, they're a foot taller. So they're very complicated, there is a lot of operational complexities to complying and we'r
componenttext: So yes. Obviously, I think if you add up TRID plus other servicing rules, print them out, put them on the floor and stand them next to me, they're a foot taller. So they're very complicated, there is a lot of operational complexities to complying and we're working very hard at doing that. I will say in the quarter, we did as part of being cautious about making sure that we're complying, our cycle times were a couple of days -- few days worsened. And so volumes are related, volumes are a little lower than we would have otherwise seen, that's a lot and that's just timing and it's just days. But not really from a financial results, effective because of the way we recognize the revenue. So I would call it, a little bit of teething problems across the industry, by the way, not just us. Nothing significant. We are going to get the work finished. And -- so it's tough but it is what it is.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a follow-up question on your portfolio. You look like you can grow your residential loans by about $11 billion. With -- last quarter, you said there was a mix between agency and jumbo. If a big chunk of it's agency, can you give us your thoughts
componenttext: And then a follow-up question on your portfolio. You look like you can grow your residential loans by about $11 billion. With -- last quarter, you said there was a mix between agency and jumbo. If a big chunk of it's agency, can you give us your thoughts on portfolio on that agency product?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it's about 60% jumbos, 40% agency or conventional conforming. And it's the best execution business. When we look at the better economics between selling or portfolio-ing the mortgage, we'll generally choose the best of economics. But we also prefe
componenttext: Yes. So it's about 60% jumbos, 40% agency or conventional conforming. And it's the best execution business. When we look at the better economics between selling or portfolio-ing the mortgage, we'll generally choose the best of economics. But we also prefer the annuity nature of the NII, the lower servicing risk and a better capital efficiency. So it has been the case over the course of the last several quarters, that it has been the best execution to portfolio these mortgages and actually they're generating a nice return on equity.

componenttext: One quick follow-up, Marianne. You've had some pretty big tax gains the last couple of quarters, running below 30% on your tax rate. At some point, do you pull forward future benefits and run with a higher tax rate in the future?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we have had pretty big tax gains over the course of last -- most notably obviously last quarter, over the last couple of years. Most of those related to the fullest call it '03 through '08 tax periods when we were going through the financial crisis and
componenttext: So we have had pretty big tax gains over the course of last -- most notably obviously last quarter, over the last couple of years. Most of those related to the fullest call it '03 through '08 tax periods when we were going through the financial crisis and so some of the matters were more complex and we took appropriate reserving decisions on that. There are many left of those very complicated matters ahead of us and so we wouldn't expect to see the same sort of size of tax benefit going forward as we'd seen in the past. But we had some this quarter. So we'll have a few and generally speaking, they are -- because of the nature of the reserving for tax, generally speaking, we take a conservative approach and a bias to the positive but it could be much more plus or minus zero at this point.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a Board decision and so neither have we received that guidance from the regulators nor have we done CCAR and had that discussion yet with the Board. But we have generally said that the Board likes to have the flexibility to increase dividends b
componenttext: Well, it's a Board decision and so neither have we received that guidance from the regulators nor have we done CCAR and had that discussion yet with the Board. But we have generally said that the Board likes to have the flexibility to increase dividends by the time. And we have had our dividends most recently sort of at or close to that soft cap. So we would like that capacity and I would imagine that over time, it may be used but again, it is a Board decision, not a management decision.

componenttext: And then just one last follow-up on the G-SIB buffer, obviously you guys have done an incredible job in bringing it down to where it is today. When do you expect the regulators to put you into that bucket, assuming you guys are obviously looking at the same types of numbers?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So from -- we do have it in pro forma. And so first of all, I would say the following: right now, my understanding and if I'm wrong, forgive me, is that it's your stock balance sheet 2 years prior that would drive your GSIBs 2 years forward.  But the real
componenttext: So from -- we do have it in pro forma. And so first of all, I would say the following: right now, my understanding and if I'm wrong, forgive me, is that it's your stock balance sheet 2 years prior that would drive your GSIBs 2 years forward.  But the reality, if you ask my opinion given that we're going to be reporting quarterly going forward and because of the likelihood that GSIB may or may not feature into CCAR, I think it's going to be less important necessarily what you are at any moment in time. But the way you're projecting to be, or stay. So I suspect that we will get the benefit potentially of this. Not today, we have just closed our balance sheet. But I think that it's going to need to be a little bit more dynamic going forward as it gets potentially into introducing a stress test. But I don't know that.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to JPMorgan Chase's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] We will now go live to the presentation. Please stand by. At this time, I would like to turn the call
componenttext:
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to JPMorgan Chase's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] We will now go live to the presentation. Please stand by. 
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to JPMorgan Chase's Chairman and CEO, Jamie Dimon; and Chief Financial Officer, Marianne Lake. Ms. Lake, please go ahead.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning, everyone. I'm going to take you through the earnings presentation, which is available on our website. Please refer to the disclaimer regarding forward-looking statements at the back of the presentation. Starting on Pag
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good morning, everyone. I'm going to take you through the earnings presentation, which is available on our website. Please refer to the disclaimer regarding forward-looking statements at the back of the presentation. 
Starting on Page 1. Firm reported net income of $5.5 billion, EPS of $1.35 and return on tangible common equity of 12% on $24 billion of revenue. And despite the general market backdrop in energy, our results this quarter were quite good and pretty straightforward. 
[indiscernible] remain on solid footing, leading robust growth in business drivers and strong financial performance. In consumer, we saw double-digit growth in deposits year-on-year, healthy loan growth across products, driving 17% [ph] core loan growth at the firm and high single digits for sales volume. The wholesale businesses performed in line or better than expectations as set on Investor Day and delivered decent financial results in challenging markets, significant volatility and global macro uncertainty. 
The firm's result included one significant item, $773 million of wholesale credit loss, of which $529 million related to oil and gas reserves, and $162 million related to Metals & Mining reserve. We're generally in line with our guidance. We also experienced some charge-offs this quarter in these sectors totaling $48 million, which were already contemplated in the Investor Day guidance [indiscernible] $4.75 billion [ph] at [indiscernible] this year. 
While oil prices have increased somewhat [indiscernible] we do remain near historically low levels and [indiscernible] we don't expect the recoveries to be strong. Further, natural gas, which is a meaningful cost of our portfolio does remain [indiscernible] We don't feel the current prices are positioned to spur meaningful restarted production, and many of the cost reductions and conservation actions that have been taken are not easily and quickly reversed. Therefore, the impact of oil prices is somewhat asymmetric on credit costs. Reserves are named specific, based on downgrades reflecting the actual financial conditions and liquidity position of borrowers. As such, we likely will see some incremental reserve builds for the rest of the year, but they will be increasingly situation-specific and our ability to estimate them will improve over time. However, using reasonable stress assumptions on draws, downgrades and considering spillover effects to [indiscernible] closely related companies, those incremental reserves could reach $500 million, plus or minus, this year, but with a very high degree of variability around that number. We continue to believe overall our client base is relatively well positioned to weather this downturn, and we will be there to support them whenever feasible. 
We also monitor the contagion. And aside from experiencing a couple of name-specific issues on very closely related companies and observing some general stress and oil regions, we're not seeing anything broad-based and would not expect losses to be significant. 
Moving on to Page 2. Pausing on this page for just a moment, a few comments on overall revenue and expense. We told you that the first rate hike, together with our strong loan growth, would drive 2016 NII higher by $2 billion, and the $700 million increase in net interest income year-over-year that you see here is in line with that. However, sequentially, NII was only up slightly as expected given the absence of certain securities gains that we had in the fourth quarter as well as day count. 
Noninterest revenue was down $1.5 billion year-on-year, primarily driven by the market environments in both the Corporate & Investment Bank as well as asset management, with the biggest drivers being lower IBCs and Fixed Income Markets revenues, in both case, versus a very strong prior year. 
Adjusted expense of $13.9 billion was down 2% year-on-year on lower performance-based compensation while continuing to self-fund incremental investment in growth. 
Turning to Page 3. The firm's fully phased-in advance CET1 ratio was 11.7%, standardized at 11.9%. The improvement to both ratios was driven primarily by net capital generation. Recall that we ended the year with very low levels of inventory. And as expected, we did see that reverse with our spot balance sheet up $70 billion quarter-on-quarter, reflecting growth in deposits and an increase in trading assets and secured financing activity. This also drove a slight increase in RWA, [indiscernible] runoff and model calibration. Firm SLR improve to 6.6%, and we returned $3 billion of net capital to shareholders this quarter, including $1.3 billion of net repurchases and common dividends of $0.44 a share. Lastly, the Fed did not object to a $1.9 billion increase in our capital plan, giving incremental capacity for repurchases next quarter. 
Moving on to Page 4 in Consumer & Community Banking. You'll notice that we consolidated consumer into one page. And for your reference, we've included the old pages in the appendix. CCB generated $2.5 billion [ph] of net income and an ROE of 19% with strength across all lines of business. And TNS just announced that for the fourth consecutive year, we are the #1 consumer retail bank, reflecting our ability to attract, satisfy and retain customers. The fundamental business drivers remained strong with average loans up 12% year-on-year and core loans up 25%, driven by mortgage and auto, but with strength across products. And we saw record deposit growth of $50 billion, [ph] up 10%. We added over 1 million household since last year, and are active mobile customer base was up 19%. Revenues of $11.1 billion was up 4% year-on-year and up 1% sequentially, if you exclude from last quarter nearly $200 million from the square IPO and a branch sale. In Consumer & Business Banking, revenue was up 4% year-on-year, reflecting that record deposit growth I mentioned as well as higher account and transaction volume and investment revenue up 4% despite the challenging environment. Mortgage revenue increased 7% on higher MSR risk management and strong loan growth, partially offset by lower servicing revenue. Card solutions and auto, revenue was up 2% on strong auto loan and lease growth, 8% growth in card sales and 12% in merchant processing volumes, all of which more than offset the impact of card renegotiations. 
Expense was down 2% year-on-year with an overhead ratio improving to 55% as we continue to make progress against our commitments, more than offsetting $200 million in incremental marketing and auto lease growth. Finally, credit trends in the consumer businesses continue to be favorable. 
Now turning to Page 5 on the Corporate & Investment Bank. CIB reported net income of $2 billion on revenue of $8.1 billion and an ROE of 11%. In banking, IB revenue was $1.2 billion, down 24% year-on-year, driven by lower equity and debt underwriting fees, but in line with the market, which was down 27%. We continue to rank #1 in global IBCs and rank #1 in 3 regions: North America, EMEA and LatAm. 
It was another strong quarter for advisory, up 8%, versus [indiscernible] decline of 15%. We gained share, ranking #1 as we benefited from a number of deals that were announced in 2015 and closed this quarter. 
Equity underwriting fees were down 49%, in line with the market as volatility kept issuers on the sideline. We maintained our #1 rank globally and increased our lead. Debt underwriting fees were down 35%. And while we were down more than the market, it can be explained by a tough comparison with several large acquisition finance deals in the first quarter of last year as well as being conflicted out of several large deals this quarter. 
In terms of the outlook, we expect a sequential decline in M&A to be more than offset by an increase in debt and equity underwriting, if the recent market improvements continue. 
Treasury Services revenue was down 5%, driven by business simplification. Lending revenue was down 31%, primarily reflecting mark-to-market changes on both hedges of accrual loans and securities received from restructurings. 
Moving on the market. Markets revenue was $5.2 billion and was down 11% year-on-year, reflecting decent performance given the environment and especially in light of the strength in the third quarter of 2015 where we saw elevated client wallet and trading, particularly in January last year, particularly around the Swiss francs event. In fact, if you indulge me, adjusting for our outperformance year-over-year, results would have been down by mid-single-digits. 
Fixed-income revenue was down 13%. The first couple of months of this quarter, as you know, were challenging across markets, but some stability returned in March. And overall, I would characterize the quarter as seeing reasonably solid client activity. But given the market backdrop, it was more difficult to monetize loans. We saw better performance in rates and lower performance across other asset classes. 
Equity Markets revenue was down 5%. And although flows were steady, idiosyncratic events and sharp moves returned for our clients. Those on the way down and back up. Asian equities continued to outperform driven by market volatility, particularly in Japan. 
With respect to the second quarter, the relative stability we saw in March has continued into April so far. However, it's also the case that markets are still quite illiquid in certain parts and will be prone to somewhat on that direction. So while investors have started to deploy cash and capital markets are wide open for well-understood names, they still remain in caution for more challenging issuers. Although there's been noise in the data globally, there is an emerging belief that it's fundamentally better but we need to continue to see no downplay surprises. And as such, we remain somewhat cautious about the second quarter. 
Securities Services revenues was $881 million in line with guidance. Credit Adjustments & Other was a loss of $336 million, mainly driven by CVA on spread widening. Credit costs of $459 million were driven by reserve builds for oil and gas and Metals & Mining, as discussed earlier. And finally, expense of $4.8 billion was down 15% year-on-year driven by lower performance-based compensation and lower legal expense, with a [indiscernible] ratio for the quarter of 32%. 
Moving on to Page 6 on Commercial Banking. The Commercial Bank generated net income of $500 million on revenue of $1.8 billion and and ROE of 11%. Outside of credit cost for Oil & Gas, the first quarter was very solid performance. Revenue was up 4% year-on-year driven by higher loan balances and deposits, net interest income offset by lower IBC -- IB revenues versus the record last year. Expense of $713 million was up 1% year-on-year and down 5% quarter-on-quarter, but in line with recent trends, if you exclude the impairment taken on leased corporate aircraft last quarter. We saw strong growth in our loan book with average loan balances up 13% year-on-year and 3% quarter-on-quarter and with portfolios spreads relatively flat for a couple of quarters now. 
Our commercial real estate business continued to exceed the industry with growth of 18% year-on-year, reflecting superior execution while maintaining credit discipline. In C&I, loans were up 9% year-on-year driven by robust originations in Corporate Client Banking. Finally, on credit, we added $300 million to reserves, mostly related to oil and gas, but we continue to see very low net charge-offs. 
Moving on to Page 7 in asset management. Asset Management reported net income of $587 million with a 30% pretax margin and 25% ROE. Revenue of $3 billion was down 1% year-on-year driven by weaker market and lower brokerage revenues. Excluding the impact of the sale of an asset this quarter, which contributed $150 million to the revenue number, adjusted revenue, AUM and client assets were down each, generally line with our market. Expense of $2.1 billion was down 5% year-on-year, largely driven by lower performance-based compensation. Despite these lower markets, we saw positive long-term flows of $12 billion this quarter with strength in fixed income, multi-asset and alternatives and including the benefit of a large mandate, being partially offset by outflows in equity products given volatility. Our long-term investment performance remains strong with 80% of mutual fund AUM ranked in the first or second quartiles over 5 years. 
Loan balances of $110 billion were up 7% year-on-year with record mortgage balances up 20% and solid growth in traditional lending. 
Before I move on, as you're aware, the Department of Labor issued the final fiduciary [indiscernible] It's a long and complex set of requirements and details will matter. It will take time to fully digest. On first read, there are no significant new provisions from the proposal that would change our position, which means that we've been a fiduciary for over 150 years. And based on our current advisory business, we're confident in our ability to adjust and be successful. And that's one of the biggest positives is the longer time to implement, which allows us to be even better prepared. 
Skipping Page 8, as we actually have nothing significant to call out on corporate, I will move on to the outlook on Page 9. We've included our guidance from Investor Day on the page, and it's unchanged, so I won't go through it. But just 2 new points to highlight. For asset management, the first quarter revenues adjusted for the $150 million were a little over $2.8 billion. And assuming relatively constructive markets, we would expect those revenues in the second quarter to be flat to up, but to be less than $3 billion. And obviously, expense will also be flat to up, in line with those revenues, on performance-based compensation. 
In the Commercial Bank, we expect revenues will be up modestly on continued loan growth, but we also expect expenses to increase to about $725 million as we add bankers and execute on our technology and product investment strategies. The upshot of which is we expect provision net revenue for the Commercial Bank to be relatively in line with first quarter. 
Before moving to Q&A, I want to make a few comments about the news this morning regarding living wills. Obviously, we were disappointed with the conclusion reached by the joint agencies on our resolution plan. We have taken this planning process very seriously, and we believe we made substantial progress. Having said that, the most important thing is we worked with our regulators to understand their feedback fully and in more detail, and we are fully committed to meeting the expectations. 
So wrapping up, despite challenging market conditions, we delivered really quite good performance in the quarter, with diversification allowing us to perform well in difficult environments and be there for our clients. 
Operator, you can open up to Q&A.

componenttext: Marianne, maybe a couple of questions on energy. You noted that the provision was slightly above your guidance in turn -- this quarter relative to what you mentioned you thought it might be in late February. I guess I'm curious in terms of what your expectations are in terms of your guidance relative to potential drawdowns, particularly in the $10 billion of high-yield loans that you have undrawn and what your ability is to potentially mitigate potential drawdowns based on the financial condition of your borrowers.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, Matt, so the first thing I would say is, with respect to Oil & Gas up, honestly, I think, $529 million is pretty close to 500, plus or minus, so that was pretty much in line. Well, you're seeing it a little bit higher, it was on Metals & Mining's. We
componenttext: So, Matt, so the first thing I would say is, with respect to Oil & Gas up, honestly, I think, $529 million is pretty close to 500, plus or minus, so that was pretty much in line. Well, you're seeing it a little bit higher, it was on Metals & Mining's. We were expecting close to 100. And there were a couple of extra downgrades that came during the quarter. And that kind of timing is going to happen. It doesn't change the overall -- the perspective for us. With respect to the draws, when we -- when I gave sort of indicative guidance about what you might expect to see potentially in the rest of the year in terms of reserve builds, we do try to take into consideration the likelihood that we will see incremental draws. And clearly, we will work with borrowers to try and help them such that that may not be necessary. And in other cases, we can reduce our exposure in redetermination cases, but we will expect to see some draws. And that's contemplated in our guidance. So I want to make sure that everyone understood that we tried to be very complete. So this is not just Oil & Gas and Metals & Mining as [indiscernible] would suggest. We've looked at very closely related companies in shipping and marine transportation and the like. So we're trying to be very complete.

But I gave you context around what we're expecting in terms of reserves. So they will go up, but not to numbers that I would consider to be large in the context of our wholesale portfolio.

componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a positively reasonable question. And obviously, when we look at growth in CRE or [indiscernible] real estate businesses, 18%, it's an obvious question, "Are you doing something different?" And the answer is, "No, we're not." We haven't changed
componenttext: Yes, it's a positively reasonable question. And obviously, when we look at growth in CRE or [indiscernible] real estate businesses, 18%, it's an obvious question, "Are you doing something different?" And the answer is, "No, we're not." We haven't changed our geographies. We haven't changed our risk appetite. It just simply is a case that we had a good process, and we continue to focus on our sort of capabilities and our core segments. But we've been able to take advantage of the opportunity because our process is better, and to a lesser degree, but nonetheless, to a degree, given that the CMBS market has been somewhat disrupted.

componenttextpreview: I have a question on the living wills. The indication today was that there were 4 areas that you needed to enhance. Liquidity was one of those. And I was a little surprised to see that given the strength of your liquidity book. I guess what I'm wondering
componenttext: I have a question on the living wills. The indication today was that there were 4 areas that you needed to enhance. Liquidity was one of those. And I was a little surprised to see that given the strength of your liquidity book. I guess what I'm wondering is, does the living wills submission and the changes that you have to make have an impact on your current business at all? In other words, the need to build liquidity to meet the requirements that the regulators have? Or this is in a obviously worst-case scenario, you would build at that time?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that's obviously, we're having only received the specific feedback less than 24 hours ago. We still have to get into the analysis phase about what it all means. I would start with your opening comments that considering our liquidity, it was a surprise.
componenttext: So that's obviously, we're having only received the specific feedback less than 24 hours ago. We still have to get into the analysis phase about what it all means. I would start with your opening comments that considering our liquidity, it was a surprise. bit of a statement about adequacy. Honestly, JP Morgan's liquidity, which is very significant, as you know, but it's really about how we analyze and think about that at the materially [indiscernible] level and the inter-affiliate nature of how we fund our entities. So I can't tell you with any clarity exactly what will be required as we get into the analysis. It wouldn't be my current expectation that they would require us to meaningful overall new liquidity actions, but we have to do the work.

componenttext: Again, just based on the -- based on our preliminary read, I think it's going to be significant work to meet expectations of the regulators. And our plan already has us doing a lot of work around actual real signification of legal entities and other things. So I don't know that they're going to be significant changes. It's not my primary expectation that there would be, but we do need to have a moment to go through the details.

componenttext: The liquidity of the company is extraordinary. We have $400 billion in central banks around the world. $300 billion of AA+ short-duration securities. Just about $300 billion of very short-term secured -- really top-quality repo, type of stuff like that. Trading book is $300 billion, which is mostly very liquid kind of stuff. So liquidity is extraordinary.

componenttext: And I would just say, again, we need to do the work to figure out obviously with the response to that will be, but it is encouraging that some plans were found to be credible 4 largest financial institutions and they have been able to adequately show the preparedness. We're confident we should be able to do the same. We just need to make sure that we understand the details of what it is that we don't have in our plan today that we need to change, and we're committed to doing it.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, absolutely. I just wanted -- if we use the industry codes the way that you could if you want to expand your thinking to just what effectively considered to be in oil and gas company, you would miss out on, for example, a marine shipping company
componenttext: Yes, yes, absolutely. I just wanted -- if we use the industry codes the way that you could if you want to expand your thinking to just what effectively considered to be in oil and gas company, you would miss out on, for example, a marine shipping company that all they do is ship oil. And therefore, their financial condition and their performance is going to be directly related to the health of the energy sector. Those companies, we have identified them specifically. They are managed within our energy risk team. They are not managed by different teams. So I would simply saying that some of the companies that we are watching, in 1 or 2 small cases, that have experienced some stress, are not traditional energy companies, but their condition is directly related to oil and gas.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then underneath loan growth, which is obviously very strong, what are your people on their front saying about commercial real estate? Are there any changes in terms of underwriting, metrics that your front-line people are seeing since -- that we are s
componenttext: And then underneath loan growth, which is obviously very strong, what are your people on their front saying about commercial real estate? Are there any changes in terms of underwriting, metrics that your front-line people are seeing since -- that we are starting to see in certain markets like multifamily, which you guys have already identified as some weak spots? Are there an underwriting issues that are cropping up now that you didn't see 3 months ago or 6 months ago?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So -- obviously, not for us. I would say that it's competitive. And as we sort of -- C&I space is very competitive. Financial space is very competitive, but it's not irrational. And we aren't seeing -- or at least we are not seeing very rational proposal
componenttext: So -- obviously, not for us. I would say that it's competitive. And as we sort of -- C&I space is very competitive. Financial space is very competitive, but it's not irrational. And we aren't seeing -- or at least we are not seeing very rational proposal structure and risk. Meanwhile, we haven't changed our risk appetite. We haven't changed our underwriting standards. We continue to have lower LTVs and higher debt coverage ratios pretty consistently with consistent geographies. So speaking for JPMorgan specifically, there's been no change in our underwriting standards. In fact, if anything, since the last crisis or the last recession, we tightened our underwriting standards and we've moved away from some of the riskier types of that business, so homebuilders and a lot of construction loan business.

componenttext: That was a very serious CEO letter that you had in annual report. But 2 questions related to that. One would be, you -- Jamie, you indicate the potential for higher interest rates and just looking for some more color into why you think that's the case and if you're preparing the bank for a scenario of higher rates or you just trying to set the tone of the top or perhaps being contrarian. Can you give some technical factors in the CEO later. And then the second thing is just the contrast between what you have in the CEO letter, liquidity, trading, governance oversight with the living will letter that came out today. And just a follow-up on the earlier question, do you have to simply write a better resolution plan? Or might you have to change a little bit the way you do business? And does this make you have a more conservative CCAR act?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I'll start and then Jamie can add to it. So on the interest rate point, it -- pretty consistent with what we said over time, which is we have to -- the belief that the U.S. economy is continuing to move in the right direction, that the consumer is o
componenttext: Mike, I'll start and then Jamie can add to it. So on the interest rate point, it -- pretty consistent with what we said over time, which is we have to -- the belief that the U.S. economy is continuing to move in the right direction, that the consumer is on solid footing and that despite the noise in the data and some of the volatility in the markets, global growth will continue, albeit at a moderate pace. And obviously, the stability in the markets in March is continue to help us with that, [indiscernible]. So that, coupled with the fact that the Fed themselves -- while very dovish in their narratives in the minutes and also their dots are continuing to talk about gradual increases, and the debate around rates has kind of [indiscernible] so we don't particularly run the company with the a day-to-day beyond what's going to happen with interest rates. We are positioned for rising rates, as you know, and have been, but we also understand what the performance of the company looks like if there were no more rate rises or when we stress our portfolio in lots of different ways. So we are positioned for rising rates. But as a central piece of that will happen. The market is pricing less than one hike this year. The Fed that say 2. Our research says 2. We just have to wait and see. I'll also start and then Jamie can jump in on the living will thing, but we have to take it that face value in discussions with the regulators, that we need to meet their requirements, whatever they may be, all the rules, with its capital, rates liquidity, stress testing, with its was solution plans. And if you do that and satisfy them, then we can continue to operate the company the way that we think it is best for our clients and communities around the world. And so at this point, we need to remediate and address the issues and the feedback they've given us and resubmit the plan or assessment that we hope will be credible and that certainly that we will commit to do. And that's what we're focused on.

componenttext: I don't -- I mean [indiscernible] we're trying to meet all the regulations, all the rules and all the requirements. It's been -- we've been doing that now for 5 or 6 years. [indiscernible] 5 or 6, it's been 5 or 6 years since [indiscernible] we have to conform to it.

componenttext: And I think it's easy to overlook the [indiscernible] is our statement where there's the acknowledgment that progress has been made and none of the feedback in the letter negates the significant progress about the industry on capital liquidity, stress testing. So is consistent but we have more to do and we'll do it.

componenttext: And it is a straight stuff, I wasn't predicting it. I'm simply saying that I think there's a chance it will be different than what people expect, and I'm being a little -- as it'll be gradual until it's sudden.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016

componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Brian Foran with Autonomous.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder, on trading, you -- appreciate that you reported first, so you haven't seen the market debt. But to questions around the whole thesis about the last man standing versus restructures. One, do you have any sense of whether you're performance overal
componenttext: I wonder, on trading, you -- appreciate that you reported first, so you haven't seen the market debt. But to questions around the whole thesis about the last man standing versus restructures. One, do you have any sense of whether you're performance overall and really FIC represented market share gains or not this quarter. And then two, with some of the guidance coming out of European banks, in particular, being very poor and some of the restructurings may be accelerating steam, is there any thought around comp and maybe using that as a lever to improve returns over the remainder of the year and into next?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016

componenttext: So starting -- so obviously, the first to read out, and it's very difficult when you think about performance because you also have to think about the relative performance in the comparable periods in prior years and the like. So I would say that down mid-single digits, adjusted, so what we consider to have been outperformance last year is really quite good performance. So I don't know that we gained share. But I certainly think we protected share, and it may differ across the different product set. But if in a general, feel pretty good about our performance and we have -- know anything to the contrary.

componenttext: Yes. And then with respect to sort of restructuring and whether that presents opportunities for us broadly defined, including income position for a better, we pay for performance. And you can see our cost of revenue ratio of 32% this quarter is in line with the ratio in the first quarter of last year, and in fact, the first quarter of the year before. So lower obviously lower revenues. But a fair pay for the performance. And obviously, we intend to ensure that we are competitive. But we're not going to take any direct actions as a result of that. componenttext: Just a question on expenses. First, was there any legal expense in the quarter? And then just a broader next question, Marianne, are the incremental expense savings you're getting from your programs fall into the bottom line? Is it some of it getting reinvesting like in CCB? I notice of the headcount is up a little bit on Page 11, just the last couple of quarters, is that reflect light like reinvestment of the cost saves? And then just on the legal side, if anything this quarter.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on legal, I would -- so the number is sort of 0, peak exercise is a positive up the tax we did some true-ups as our assessment of penalties, so actually, net-net, about 0 this quarter, which take it for the quarter, but it doesn't predict the future. I
componenttext: So on legal, I would -- so the number is sort of 0, peak exercise is a positive up the tax we did some true-ups as our assessment of penalties, so actually, net-net, about 0 this quarter, which take it for the quarter, but it doesn't predict the future. In terms of expenses, so we talk at our Investor Day, Gordon, in particular, but also Daniel, that we are continuing to invest in our businesses, and across the board in fact, I think, bankers and technology and digital, digitizing, et cetera. So we continue to do that across the businesses. And I mentioned in the CCB page that the net expenses, albeit down, include the self-funding $200 million of incremental investments year-over-year and growth. But you did notice the headcount in the consumer businesses is up slightly. And that's a combination of the investments we're making in technology and digital. That's about 500 overheads, and the other 1,500 is increasing part-time staffing in the branches so that we have flexibility to make sure that we have loading at the right times of day or making sure the customer experience is good. So I would characterize it all as very consistent. And yes, we continue to invest, and that is in part what you're seeing in the headcount in CCB.

componenttext: And you said new credit card fee [indiscernible] 1.5% back. We're doing a lot of stuff in Chase Pay. You're -- so the Starbucks thing. We applied atop digital sites and we just -- we continue to win awards in the consumer banks. So we'll always be investing there.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: You feel that a lot of questions on energy and credit quality. But taking a step back, given that the delinquency statistics outside of energy still remain fairly stable, could you give us an outlook for how you think credit quality trends will play out f
componenttext: You feel that a lot of questions on energy and credit quality. But taking a step back, given that the delinquency statistics outside of energy still remain fairly stable, could you give us an outlook for how you think credit quality trends will play out for the rest of the year if the base case is slow growth in the U.S.?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it is our expectation across both the consumer and the wholesale businesses outside of energy that the credit trends will remain favorable -- credit will be relatively benign. We're not expecting to see material increases except for the fact that we're
componenttext: So it is our expectation across both the consumer and the wholesale businesses outside of energy that the credit trends will remain favorable -- credit will be relatively benign. We're not expecting to see material increases except for the fact that we're growing our loan portfolio. So when we did Investor Day, talked about charge-offs this year will go up year-on-year. And they'll go up to potentially as high as $4.75 billion, but half of that will be on the back of the fact that we're growing our portfolios and so we just have natural sort of BAU levels of charge-offs on that and then the other half would be in energy. So we're not expecting or seeing at this point anything other than good credit quality for the rest of 2016 outside of the obvious.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just one more follow-up question on the living will. Could you help us understand what you think the regulators meant in terms of if the remediation is not met by October 1 of this year, that there could be more stringent requirements? Would th
componenttext: Great. And just one more follow-up question on the living will. Could you help us understand what you think the regulators meant in terms of if the remediation is not met by October 1 of this year, that there could be more stringent requirements? Would that -- could that possibly mean higher capital or liquidity standards if the expectations aren't met by October? I guess we always thought of the living will as more of a cost issue rather than a further tax on regulatory ratios.

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I will start by saying that, as you know, our regulators have extraordinary powers over a wide ranges of requirements for us, regardless in many ways of influencing those. And you're familiar with most of them. It is absolutely the case that as you loo
componenttext: So I will start by saying that, as you know, our regulators have extraordinary powers over a wide ranges of requirements for us, regardless in many ways of influencing those. And you're familiar with most of them. It is absolutely the case that as you look at the resolution process that there are provisions that talk about if remediation is not satisfactory with or cured within a 2-year period, there are -- there's a possibility the regulators could jointly decide or may jointly decide to take other actions that could increase capital or liquidity or leverage or operating model discussion. So obviously, they do have those powers. It -- October is not that far away. We're going to do our very, very best to make sure that we put our best foot forward and remediate issues and then we have another submission in July 2017. So not to suggest that we won't fully remediate to the very best of our ability, but the living will process expect to continue to be somewhat iterative of the next several cycles. And we will continue to push our best to raise the bar, and I'm certain the bar will continue to be raised on us, as it should.

componenttext: If I look at the first quarter net interest income, which was at least better than what I had, good NIM, and think about your full year outlook, I think it literally implies flattish net interest income dollars from here. And I'm just wondering if that's too little of an interpretation or if there are going to be some offsets in loan growth from, say, lower long-term rates as we think about the rest of the year?

headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So we talked about the fact that if there's no change in rates and if we continue to grow our loans, we do expect our NII to grow up by $2 billion. And so you're right, if you look at the run rate right now, that would be relatively flat from here.
componenttext: Okay. So we talked about the fact that if there's no change in rates and if we continue to grow our loans, we do expect our NII to grow up by $2 billion. And so you're right, if you look at the run rate right now, that would be relatively flat from here. I think, in our favor, because of easing still going on around the rest of the world and the sort of the fed comments in a bit lower reprice in the industry generally, that's in our favor. But -- and much more sensitive to the [indiscernible] end rates. So I'm not suggesting that the long end of the curve has no impact. It's relatively modest. So -- $2 billion, maybe a little more, the biggest driver of significantly higher NII about that guidance would be if we had another hike earlier than December.

Have you found that the be difficult in terms of modeling? headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So obviously, not been able to talk specifically about our plans that we submitted because we just [indiscernible] and we haven't had any feedback and confidential. But I would tell you that obviously, negative rights it will further [indiscernible]
componenttext: Okay. So obviously, not been able to talk specifically about our plans that we submitted because we just [indiscernible] and we haven't had any feedback and confidential. But I would tell you that obviously, negative rights it will further [indiscernible] in the scenario. It's not the first time that we've thought about it, and it's not the first time that we've experienced in at least in other parts of the world, in Europe, Japan and elsewhere. So we have had [indiscernible] discussions. We understand broadly what we think we would do and what would happen to our balance sheet. We can model it, and we can affect it. So in that sense now -- I mean obviously, we'll try to work the process. It is to be a future CCAR. You're absolutely right that year-over-year, our launch point is a higher level of capital and our balance sheet and our credit quality continues to improve and our risk levels are not materially changed. So as a general matter, we would hope and we've also added press. So the general matter, we don't have incremental capacity. But nothing inconsistent with what we have said externally, which is that the board would like, over time, to continue to have the capacity to potentially increase dividends. And that we would like the capacity to -- within a reasonable range, repurchase of stock over that framework that we have used to submit our plan.

componenttext: So Marianne, within the asset management segment, you noted that the revenues were down are in line with the market. But if we isolate the fee income components to exclude some of the gains you highlighted as well as other income, the revenues declined by double-digit both quarter-on-quarter and year-on-year, which is a bit more pronounced than what we had expected. And I was hoping you could speak to maybe some of the factors outside of the market declines that are maybe impacting revenues in that business, specifically what you're seeing in terms of retail engagement and maybe whether you're seeing an improvement in sentiment now that the markets have recovered pretty nicely of the February trough?

componenttext: So if I do the sort of -- I don't want to use the word -- if I adjust for the full impact of the asset sale that was in the quarter, not just the $150 million in this quarter, but also the revenues that were present with respect to that in the first quarter of last year, my adjusted revenues are down about 4% to the market that, on average, while I appreciate the recovered in March, but the market, on average, for the quarter was down around 5%. So we would just characterize that as generally in line. And similarly, if you do adjustments on the balance sheet side, the assets under management and client assets. So certainly, you can speak to Jason afterwards and reconcile our numbers so that we're not confusing each other. And what was second part of your question?

componenttext: Retail engagement. So retail engagement picked up in March, as you would expect. We saw positive flows. We obviously saw a negative flows for the quarter. headline: JPMorgan Chase & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So no, nothing has changed in the competitive landscape, including in co-brand. It's still very competitive, albeit that we are -- yes, we solidly bit of deceleration in sales growth year-over-year last year. We've seen that trend back positively fo
componenttext: Okay. So no, nothing has changed in the competitive landscape, including in co-brand. It's still very competitive, albeit that we are -- yes, we solidly bit of deceleration in sales growth year-over-year last year. We've seen that trend back positively for us this year. So we feel good about that. And we've been increasing our marketing spend. And Jamie, just say we launched Freedom Unlimited quite recently. And -- it has been quite recent, but early feedback is very positive with respect to Freedom. We've seeing 50% [ph] increases in activity and interest. This is going to [indiscernible] cannibalization a lot of products. We would expect that. But so far, so good. And we just like to give our customers choices and is being favorably.

componenttext: So the Manheim is down slightly. We continue to believe and expect that it will continue to trend downwards. componenttextpreview: Okay. So in terms of run rated, the 2 biggest drivers of the [indiscernible] that we gave at investor day were the card co-brand renegotiations and the Mortgage Banking noninterest revenue. I would just point out that while we are seeing some incremental
componenttext: Okay. So in terms of run rated, the 2 biggest drivers of the [indiscernible] that we gave at investor day were the card co-brand renegotiations and the Mortgage Banking noninterest revenue. I would just point out that while we are seeing some incremental impacts of card renegotiations that will play out over the course of the year. But on the positive side, and on the positive side, Mortgage Banking, just given where rates were over the quarter has been positive, relative to said of expectations when we did Investor Day. So those things are worth noting, but we are seeing really quite good drivers and noninterest revenue levers across a consumer space generally. And debit investments in fees and accounts, in the sort of 4%, 5% range and sometimes in the range higher than that. So we continue to see exactly what we expected, which is the majority of our businesses will continue to deliver mid- to high single-digit growth and make -- they seem set to do that. The card impact will be what it will be an mortgage, NII will end up down year-over-year, whether it's $700 million or $600 million, we'll see. And so the biggest driver of that and result will be is going to be market.
